{{unreferenced|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox sports competition event | event = WSL 2018 | competition = Surf | image = JBay Open - 007.jpg | location = International | dates = 2018 | prev = [[2017 World Surf League|2017]] | next = [[2019 World Surf League|2019]] }} The '''2018 World Surf League Championship Tour''' (CT) is a professional competitive [[surfing]] league run by the [[World Surf League]], starting on 11 March 2018. Men and women compete in separate tours with events taking place from late March to mid-December, at various surfing locations around the world. Surfers receive points for their best events. The surfer with the most points at the end of the tour (after discarding their two worst results) is announced the 2018 World Surf League Champion. == 2018 Championship Tour == === 2018 Men's Championship Tour Jeep Leaderboard === Points are awarded using the following structure: {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:85%; text-align:center" |- ! Kevin DiCicco | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Air Buddy (dog)|Buddy]] * [[Michael Jeter]] * [[Kevin Zegers]] * [[Wendy Makkena]] * [[Eric Christmas]] * [[Bill Cobbs]]}} |music = Brahm Wenger |cinematography = [[Mike Southon (cinematographer)|Mike Southon]] |editing = Alison Grace |studio = [[Robert Vince|Buddy Films, Inc.]]https://catalog.afi.com/Catalog/moviedetails/60487?sid=b9476725-f97c-48ee-8221-840b3b79c808&sr=3.5802748&cp=1&pos=0 |distributor = [[Buena Vista Pictures Distribution]]https://catalog.afi.com/Catalog/moviedetails/60487?sid=b9476725-f97c-48ee-8221-840b3b79c808&sr=3.5802748&cp=1&pos=0 (United States)
[[Malofilm]] (Canada) |released = August 1, 1997 |runtime = 100 minutes |language = English |country = United States
Canada |budget = $3 million |gross = $27,771,629http://www.the-numbers.com/movie/Air-Bud#tab=summary }} '''''Air Bud''''' is a 1997 American [[comedy film]]{{cite web|url=http://www.allmovie.com/movie/air-bud-v156970|work=Allmovie|title=Air Bud|author=Deming, Mark|accessdate=April 16, 2013}} that sparked the franchise centered on the real-life dog [[Air Buddy (dog)|Air Buddy]], a cross-bred [[Golden Retriever]], who shoots basketball hoops and appears as Old Blue/Buddy. The film was financially successful, grossing $4 million in its opening weekend and totaling $27.8 million in its run against an estimated $3 million budget. ==Plot== Norm Snively, an alcoholic and bumbling clown, and his [[Golden Retriever]] Old Blue are doing a show at a child's birthday party. After Blue causes havoc at the party, Snively angrily takes him in a kennel to a dog pound (though it was the latter's own fault for throwing a ball that was too big for the former's mouth), until the kennel falls out of his truck, rendering Blue homeless. Meanwhile, 12-year-old Josh Framm has relocated with his mother Jackie and two-year-old sister Andrea from Virginia to Fernfield, Washington. Due to heartbreak over the death of his father, a pilot who died in a plane crash during a test flight due to fuel shortage, he is too shy to try out for his middle school's basketball team or to make any friends. He instead becomes the basketball team's manager, an awkward offer by Coach Joe Barker which he accepts. He practices basketball by himself in a makeshift court that he sets up in an abandoned allotment, where he meets Blue and renames him Buddy. Josh soon discovers that Buddy has the uncanny ability to play basketball, and decides to let Buddy come home with him. Jackie agrees to let him keep Buddy until Christmas and she plans to send him to the pound if his rightful owner is not located; however, she sees how loyal Buddy is and how much Josh loves him. On Christmas, Jackie lets Josh keep Buddy as a present. Following Christmas, Josh finds a tryout invitation in his locker and further realizes Buddy's talent when he discovers that he can actually shoot a hoop. These facts together prompt Josh to try out, and he gets a place on the team. At his first game, he befriends teammate Tom Stewart, but earns the disdain of star player and team bully Larry Willingham. Meanwhile, Buddy leaves the backyard, goes to the school and shows up while the game is underway. He runs into the court, disrupts the game, and causes mayhem, but the audience loves him after he scores a basket. Buddy is later caught by Josh after the game. Soon after, the dog witnesses Coach Barker abusing Tom by violently pelting him with basketballs in an attempt to make him catch better. He leads Josh, Jackie, and the school principal Ms. Pepper to the scene. As a result, Barker is fired and replaced by the school's kind-hearted engineer, former NBA player Arthur Chaney, at Josh's suggestion. As the new basketball coach, Chaney starts implementing changes in the team, including benching Larry during a game for constant ball-hogging. Angry by Chaney's decision, Buck Willingham, Larry's overbearing father, forces Larry to leave the team. Buddy becomes the mascot of the school's basketball team and begins appearing in their halftime shows. After the Timberwolves lose one game, the team has subsequent success and qualifies for the State Final. Just before the championship game, Snively appears after seeing Buddy on television. Hoping to profit out of Buddy's newfound fame, he forces Jackie to hand over Buddy, using papers proving that he is Buddy's legal owner. Knowing they do not have a choice, Jackie forces Josh to give Buddy back to Snively. After noticing that he's feeling withdrawn and depressed, Jackie regrets making Josh give up Buddy. Josh decides to rescue Buddy, suspecting he's being abused by Snively. He sneaks into Snively's backyard and finds Buddy chained up and abused again. Snively catches Josh escaping with Buddy, and pursues them in his dilapidated clown truck before crashing into a lake. Josh then decides to set Buddy free in the forest to find a new home. Initially, his team is losing at the next championship to the opposing team, which Larry turns out to have joined. Then Buddy returns for a joyful reunion for Josh and the team. When it is discovered that there is no rule that a dog can't play basketball, Buddy joins the roster and leads the team to a come from behind championship victory, with Josh scoring the game-winning buzzer beater. Snively arrives and attempts to sue the Framm family for custody of Buddy, despite that his ownership papers were ruined when he crashed into the lake. Upon seeing Buddy, Judge Cranfield is disgusted and initially reluctant to judge a case over a dog, but agrees only under a strict condition that the case be executed seriously. During the trial, Josh protests against letting Snively have Buddy, mentioning the abuse that Buddy has suffered under him, including chaining Buddy to his fence. Jackie also protests, mentioning that Buddy was much happier with their family, and that she too has seen how abusive Snively is. After hearing a number of people protest against Snively, Cranfield doesn't believe that neither one has any real evidence in claiming ownership to Buddy. Soon, Chaney arrives and suggests that Buddy chooses his owner. As a fan of Chaney, Cranfield accepts his proposal and moves the court outside to the front lawn for Buddy to choose. After Buddy rips up the rolled-up newspaper that Snively had always abused him with, Buddy chooses Josh. When Snively angrily attempts to get Buddy back by force, police officers quickly take him away and arrest him, while Josh and the rest of the citizens rejoice and gather around Buddy to welcome him to his new home. ==Cast== {{Cast listing| *[[Air Buddy (dog)|Air Buddy]] as Buddy *[[Kevin Zegers]] as Joshua "Josh" Framm *[[Wendy Makkena]] as Jacqueline "Jackie" Framm *[[Bill Cobbs]] as Coach Arthur Chaney *[[Michael Jeter]] as Norman F. "Norm" Snively *[[Eric Christmas]] as Judge Cranfield *[[Nicola Cavendish]] as Ms. Pepper *[[Brendan Fletcher]] as Lawrence "Larry" Willingham *[[Norman Browning]] as Buck Willingham *[[Stephen E. Miller]] as Coach Joseph "Joe" Barker *[[Shayn Solberg]] as Thomas "Tom" Stewart *[[Jessibelle Mather]] and [[Kati Mather]] as Andrea Framm }} Much of the on-set dog motivation (not training) were performed by Justin Sherbert (formally Justin Sherman) of Free Willy fame. The animals were pet and treated with respect by Sherbert who noted, "motivating these dogs is significantly easier than teaching a whale to flip." Sherbert remains the canine motivator at large for the Air Bud franchise. ==Home video release== ''Air Bud'' was released to VHS on December 23, 1997, and to DVD on February 3, 1998 (with an [[open matte]] aspect ratio).{{cite web |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/air_bud |title=Air Bud (1997) |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=[[Fandango Media]] |accessdate=March 6, 2018}} It was released again on March 3, 2009, in a special edition DVD set that presents the film in its [[Aspect ratio (image)|original theatrical aspect ratio]]. The special edition DVD also includes commentary from Buddy and his puppies, as the series had introduced speaking animals by that time. It was released direct-to-video in October 1999 in the UK by [[Warner Home Video]] under the [[Warner Bros. Family Entertainment]] label. ==Reception== The film received mixed reviews. It holds a [[Rotten Tomatoes]] score of 45% based on 22 reviews, with an average rating of 4.8/10. ==Sequels and spin-offs== {{main|Air Bud (series)}} The film generated one theatrical sequel, three direct-to-video sequels and a spin-off film series. In each film, Buddy learns to play a different sport while the spin offs focus on Buddy's children, the Buddies. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://buddies.disney.com/air-bud}} *{{IMDb title|0118570|Air Bud}} *{{rottentomatoes|air_bud}} *{{Mojo title|airbud}} *{{Amg title|156970}} {{The Air Bud Series}} {{Charles Martin Smith}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Air Bud}} [[Category:1997 films]] [[Category:1990s sports films]] [[Category:Films about dogs]] [[Category:American basketball films]] [[Category:American comedy films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Films about animals playing sports]] [[Category:Films set in Washington (state)]] [[Category:Films shot in British Columbia]] [[Category:Air Bud (series)]] [[Category:Walt Disney Pictures films]] [[Category:Films directed by Charles Martin Smith]] [[Category:American children's films]] [[Category:Films about animals]] [[Category:1990s sports comedy films]]

{{Infobox rugby biography | name = Alain Lorieux | image = | caption = | birth_name = | nickname = | birth_place = [[La Tronche]], France | death_date = | death_place = | height = {{height|m=1.96}} | weight = {{convert|109|kg|lb|abbr=on}} | ru_position = [[Lock (rugby union)|Lock]] | ru_nationalteam = [[France national rugby union team|France]] | ru_nationalyears = 1981-1989 | ru_nationalcaps = 31 | ru_nationalpoints = (12) | ru_ntupdate = | ru_amateuryears = 1978-1985
1985-1989
1989-1990 | ru_amateurclubs = [[FC Aix les Bains]]
[[FC Grenoble|Grenoble]]
RC Seyssens | ru_amupdate = | occupation = | family = | spouse = | children = | relatives = | school = | university = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1956|6|26}} }} '''Alain Lorieux''' (born March 26, 1956) is a retired [[France|French]] international [[rugby union]] player. He played as a lock. Lorieux played for FC Aix les Bains from 1978/79 to 1984/85, [[FC Grenoble]] from 1985/86 to 1988/89, and RC Seyssens in 1989/90. Lorieux had 31 caps for [[France national rugby union team|France]], from 1981 to 1989, scoring 3 tries, 12 points on aggregate. He earned his first cap on 5 July 1981 against Australia in a 17-15 loss at Brisbane. He played 5 times at the [[Five Nations Championship]], in 1982, 1984, 1987, 1988 and 1989, being a winner in 1988, ex-aequo with Wales, and 1989. Lorieux was called for the [[1987 Rugby World Cup]], where France was runner-up to New Zealand. He played in 5 games, scoring 2 tries, 8 points on aggregate.[http://www.espnscrum.com/statsguru/rugby/player/9172.html Alain Lorieux International Statistics] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * http://www.espnscrum.com/france/rugby/player/9172.html {{France Squad 1987 World Cup}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lorieux, Alain}} [[Category:French rugby union players]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:France international rugby union players]] [[Category:1956 births]] [[Category:People from La Tronche]] [[Category:Rugby union locks]] {{France-sport-stub}}

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Andy Kerr Stadium | nickname = | image = | location = 13 Oak Drive
[[Hamilton (village), New York|Hamilton, NY]] 13346 | coordinates = {{Coord|42.816944|-75.5452|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | opened = September 1966 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Colgate University]] | operator = [[Colgate University]] | surface = [[FieldTurf]] | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|USD]] | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Colgate Raiders]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (1991–present) | seating_capacity = 10,221 |}} '''Andy Kerr Stadium''' is a 10,221-seat [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Hamilton (village), New York|Hamilton, New York]], United States. It was dedicated in honor of former Colgate football coach [[Andrew Kerr|Andy Kerr]] in September 1966. There have been several upgrades to the facility in recent years. In 1991, the stadium added the permanent Fred Dunlap Stands on the east side of the stadium. Dunlap is a former Colgate football head coach and athletic director. In 2003, a new three story press box was constructed behind the west stands of the stadium. In 2006, the stadium added a new scoreboard with video capability. In 2007, Colgate replaced the natural grass surface with the synthetic playing surface [[FieldTurf]]. It is home to the [[Colgate University]] Raiders football and men's lacrosse teams. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I FCS football stadiums]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.gocolgateraiders.com/sports/2005/12/13/kerr.aspx Andy Kerr Stadium - Colgate Raiders] {{Colgate Raiders football navbox}} {{Patriot League football venue navbox}} {{New York college football venues}} [[Category:College football venues]] [[Category:Colgate Raiders football]] [[Category:Sports venues in Madison County, New York]] [[Category:American football venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in the United States]] [[Category:College lacrosse venues in the United States]] [[Category:Lacrosse venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:1966 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1966]] {{NewYork-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox football match | title = 2014 FIFA World Cup qualification
([[Asian Football Confederation|Asian zone]])
Group E | image = | event = | team1 = [[Bahrain national football team|Bahrain]] | team1association = {{flagicon|BHR|size=30px}} | team1score = 10 | team2 = [[Indonesia national football team|Indonesia]] | team2association = {{flagicon|IDN|size=30px}} | team2score = 0 | details = | date = 29 February 2012 | stadium = [[Bahrain National Stadium]] | city = [[Riffa]], [[Bahrain]] | referee = [[Andre El Haddad]] ([[Federation Libanaise de Football|Lebanon]]) | attendance = 3,000 | weather = Clear
{{convert|26|°C|°F}}{{cite web|title=History for Manama, Bahrain|url=http://www.wunderground.com/history/airport/OBBI/2012/2/29/DailyHistory.html?req_city=NA&req_state=NA&req_statename=NA|publisher=wunderground.com|date=2012-02-29|accessdate=2013-08-06}} }} On 29 February 2012, the [[Bahrain national football team|Bahraini]] and [[Indonesia national football team|Indonesia]] national [[association football]] teams faced each other in a [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification|qualifying match]] for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]]. The match was played at the [[Bahrain National Stadium]] in [[Riffa]], [[Bahrain]]. This match is known for the investigation called for by [[FIFA]] afterwards.{{Clarify|date=September 2015}} Before this match Bahrain needed to score nine goals in order to pass [[Qatar national football team|Qatar]] and to move on to the next round in qualifying. They also needed Qatar to lose their next match against [[Iran national football team|Iran]] but due to an 83rd-minute equalizer the game finished 2–2 and thus Qatar progressed instead of Bahrain.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/international/9117977/Fifa-security-launches-investigation-into-Bahrains-unusual-10-0-victory-over-Indonesia.html|title=Fifa security launches investigation into Bahrain's 'unusual' 10–0 victory over Indonesia|work=The Telegraph|date=2 March 2012|accessdate=2 April 2012}} == Background == Prior to the final matchday the table was: {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- !Team !{{Tooltip|Pld|Played}} !{{Tooltip|W|Won}} !{{Tooltip|D|Drawn}} !{{Tooltip|L|Lost}} !{{Tooltip|GF|Goals for}} !{{Tooltip|GA|Goals against}} !{{Tooltip|GD|Goals difference}} !{{Tooltip|Pts|Points}} |- style="background:#ccffcc;" |align=left|{{fb|IRN}} |5||3||2||0||15||3||+12||'''11''' |- style="border-bottom:3px solid green;" |align=left|{{fb|QAT}} |5||2||3||0||8||3||+5||'''9''' |- |align=left|{{fb|BHR}} |5||1||3||1||3||7||−4||'''6''' |- style="background:#ffcccc;" |align=left|{{fb|IDN}} |5||0||0||5||3||16||−13||'''0''' |- |} Before the game, [[Bahrain national football team|Bahrain]] required a winning margin of nine goals to stand any chance of progressing to the next stage.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2108614/FIFA-launch-investigation-Bahrain-10-0-win-Indonesia.html|title=FIFA launch investigation as Taylor's Bahrain win crucial World Cup qualifier 10–0|work=The Daily Mail|date=1 March 2012|accessdate=2 April 2012}} Leading up to the game, [[Indonesia national football team|Indonesia]] had lost all five matches to date in their qualification group, allowing 16 goals in the process. Internal conflict in the [[Football Association of Indonesia]] lead them to prevent all [[Indonesia Super League]] players from playing.{{cite news|url=http://www.moneycontrol.com/news/wire-news/indonesia-fa-confidentavoiding-fifa-ban_682641.html|title=Indonesia FA confident of avoiding FIFA ban|work=Reuters|date=19 March 2012|accessdate=2 April 2012}} They only sent players who play in the [[Indonesian Premier League]], although Indonesia's regular, better, and more experienced national players play in the [[Indonesia Super League]]. Indonesia was understood to have fielded inexperienced players due to this situation.{{cite news|last=Jurejko|first=Jonathan|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17220640|title=Peter Taylor's Bahrain face Fifa investigation after 10–0 win|work=BBC Sport|date=1 March 2012|accessdate=5 April 2012}} Prior to this match, Indonesia's record loss was 9–0, recorded in 1974 at the hands of [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]].{{cite news|last1=Satwiko |first1=Wimbo |last2=Rahman |first2=Anita |url=http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/sports/football-blame-game-starts-after-indonesias-10-0-loss/501839 |title=Football: Blame Game Starts After Indonesia's 10–0 Loss |work=Jakarta Globe |date=1 March 2012 |accessdate=5 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120404163909/http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/sports/football-blame-game-starts-after-indonesias-10-0-loss/501839 |archivedate=4 April 2012 |df= }} In the six previous meetings between the two teams, each team had won twice, with two matches having been drawn. ==Match summary== Indonesia started the game with an inexperienced side, with no player holding more than 12 international [[Cap (sport)|caps]].{{cite news|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/sport/soccer/bahrain-coach-says-his-team-did-nothing-wrong-in-10-0-world-cup-qualifying-drubbing-of-weakened-indonesia/story-e6frey4r-1226322523205|title=Bahrain coach says his team did 'nothing wrong' in 10–0 World Cup qualifying drubbing of weakened Indonesia|work=The Daily Telegraph (Australia)|date=10 April 2012|accessdate=13 April 2012}} This was also the international debut for eight players in the Indonesia starting line up (except [[Syamsidar]], [[Irfan Bachdim]], and [[Ferdinand Sinaga]]). [[Indonesia national football team|Indonesia]] suffered an early setback when their [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] Syamsidar was shown the [[Misconduct (association football)|red card]] in the first three minutes. After Bahrain scored the resultant penalty, they went on to be awarded a total of four penalties in the match, including three in the first half, although substitute Indonesia goalkeeper [[Andi Muhammad Guntur]] managed to save two of the four kicks. ==Match details== {{football box |date=29 February 2012 |time=16:30 [[Arabia Standard Time|AST]] |team1=[[Bahrain national football team|Bahrain]] {{flagicon|BHR}} |score=10–0 |report=[https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/preliminaries/asia/matches/round=257791/match=300172578/report.html Report] |team2={{flagicon|INA}} [[Indonesia national football team|Indonesia]] |goals1=[[Ismail Abdul-Latif|Latif]] {{goal|5|pen.|71||75}}
[[Mohammed Tayeb Al Alawi|Al Alawi]] {{goal|16||61}}
[[Mahmood Abdulrahman|Abdulrahman]] {{goal|35|pen.|42}}

Khattal]] |- | ||'''20''' ||[[Sami Mohammed]] |- | ||'''21''' ||[[Hamad Ebrahim]] |- |GK ||'''22''' ||[[Abbas Ahmed Khamis]] |- | ||'''23''' ||[[Ebrahim Al Obaildi]] |- |colspan=3|'''Manager:''' |- (Indonesian footballer)|Abdul Rahman]] || {{yel|84}} |- |colspan=3|'''Substitutes:''' |- |DF ||'''2'''||[[Sigit Meiko Susanto]] |- |MF ||'''7''' ||[[Ricky Ohorella]] || || {{subon|61}} |- |FW ||'''9''' ||[[Samsul Arif]] |- |GK ||'''12''' ||[[Andi Muhammad Guntur]] || || {{subon|4}} |- |DF ||'''16''' ||[[Rasul Zainuddin]] |- |MF ||'''21''' ||[[Abdul Abanda Rahman]] |- |DF ||'''23''' ||[[Wahyu Wijiastanto]] || || {{subon|68}} |- |colspan=3|'''Manager:''' |- |colspan=4|{{flagicon|INA}} [[Aji Santoso]] |} |} {| width=100% style="font-size: 90%" | '''Assistant referees:'''

'''Fourth official:'''
[[Radwan Ghandour]] ([[Federation Libanaise de Football|Lebanon]]) |} ==Post match== The final table was as follows: {{2014 FIFA World Cup qualification – AFC Third Round Group E|expanded=yes}} Following the match, Indonesia finished the [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification – AFC Third Round|third round]] with the worst overall record of the 20 competing teams, having scored no points at all in the round while conceding a total of 26 goals. Bahrain also failed to qualify for the next stage of qualifying, finishing with two wins, three draws and a single loss. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/preliminaries/asia/matches/round=257791/match=300172578/report.html Official match report at FIFA.com] {{FIFA World Cup 2014 Qualifiers}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bahrain 10-0 Indonesia}} [[Category:2012 in Asian football]] [[Category:FIFA World Cup qualification matches]] [[Category:2014 FIFA World Cup qualification (AFC)]] [[Category:Bahrain national football team matches]] [[Category:Indonesia national football team matches]] [[Category:2011–12 in Bahraini football]] [[Category:2011–12 in Indonesian football]] [[Category:Association football controversies]]

{{Use Australian English|date=August 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2011}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Perth’s Harley-Davidson Ballpark | nickname = | image = [[File:Baseball ground, Thornlie, Perth, WA SMC.jpg|frameless]] | caption = Baseball Park, 2007 | location = Cnr of Wilfred and Nicholson Roads, [[Thornlie, Western Australia|Thornlie]], [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]], [[Western Australia]] | coordinates = {{coord|32|3|30|S|115|56|12|E|display=it}} | broke_ground = | opened = 2004 | renovated = 2016 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = West Australian Government | operator = Baseball WA | surface = Semi-Skinned Gravel, with Grass. | construction_cost = Build $2.7million Upgrade: 2007 $200,000 Stage 1: 2016-2017 A$1.7million Stage 2: 2017-2019 A$6million | architect = | former_names = Baseball Park (2004-2010) Barbagallo Ballpark (2010-2015) | tenants = [[Baseball WA]]
[[Perth Heat]] | seating_capacity = 3,000 | dimensions = '''Left field''' - 320ft {{convert|335|ft|m|0}}
'''Left-centre''' - {{convert|370|ft|m|0}}
'''Centre field''' - 380ft {{convert|400|ft|m|0}}
'''Right-centre''' - {{convert|370|ft|m|0}}
'''Right field''' - 320ft {{convert|335|ft|m|0}} }} '''Perth Harley-Davidson Ballpark''' is home to [[Baseball WA|baseball in Western Australia]]. It was built in 2004, with a seating capacity of 500 and standing room for a further 3,000. This is the first baseball-exclusive stadium in Perth since the demolition of [[Parry Field]] in the mid-1990s. Baseball Park was the venue of the [[Claxton Shield 2007|2007 Claxton Shield]], which ran from 19 to 27 January 2007. The facility was known as Barbagallo Ballpark between mid 2010 and mid 2015, until Perth Harley-Davidson purchase the naming rights to the Stadium in 2017 for a 3 year deal. == Stage 2 development == Baseball Park underwent further expansion in 2007 in preparation for a new [[Australian Baseball League]], which was originally intended to start in late 2007. The upgrades provided increased corporate facilities and public seating.[http://www.austadiums.com/news/news.php?id=271 Perth Heat going from strength to strength] www.austadiums.com. Retrieved 15 April 2007. In 2010, the facility underwent further upgrades between the end of the [[2010 Claxton Shield|2009-2010 Claxton Shield]] season and the start of the ABL, which began in November 2010. The upgrades included a new, permanent, terraced bar, a batter's eye in centre field and an electronic scoreboard, while the outfield fences were also brought in to help fix the shortage of home runs at the venue in previous [[Claxton Shield]] seasons. Furthermore, an enclosed members area, numbered seats, an improved playing surface, upgraded corporate boxes, fences around the terraces and a new gameday office building were part of the improvements.[http://www.wa.baseball.com.au/?Page=68757 Barbagallo Ball Park Upgrades] http://www.wa.baseball.com.au. Retrieved 21 September 2010. {{clear}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.wa.baseball.com.au/ Official Baseball WA website] * [http://www.austadiums.com/stadiums/stadiums.php?id=287 Baseball Park on Austadiums.com] {{Perth Heat|state=autocollapse}} {{Australian-baseball-stadiums}} [[Category:Sports venues in Perth, Western Australia]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Australia]] [[Category:2004 establishments in Australia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2004]]

revision.text:
{{Advert|date=May 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Use Australian English|date=January 2012}} {{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Brisbane Entertainment Centre | nickname = Boondall | image = [[File:Boondall-Entertainment-Centre.jpg|250px|Brisbane Entertainment Centre]] | location = Melaleuca Drive, [[Boondall, Queensland]] 4034 | coordinates = {{coord|27|20|32|S|153|4|16|E|display=it|type:landmark_region:AU-QLD}} | broke_ground = 1985 | opened = 1986 | builder = [[Watpac]]{{cite web |url=https://davidrobins48.wordpress.com/resume/various-projects/brisbane-entertainment-centre/ |title=Brisbane Entertainment Centre |author=David James Robins |accessdate=19 November 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171201043435/https://davidrobins48.wordpress.com/resume/various-projects/brisbane-entertainment-centre/ |archivedate=1 December 2017 |df=dmy-all }} | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Queensland|Queensland State Government]] | operator = [[AEG Ogden]] | surface = Customisable | construction_cost = A$71 million
{{small|(A${{formatprice|181006429}} in 2016 dollars{{cite web|url=http://www.rba.gov.au/calculator/annualDecimal.html|title=Inflation Calculator|publisher=RBA|accessdate=10 March 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170303032708/http://www.rba.gov.au/calculator/annualDecimal.html|archivedate=3 March 2017|df=dmy-all}})}} | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Brisbane Bullets]] ([[National Basketball League (Australia)|NBL]]) (1986–1997, 2007, 2016–present) | seating_capacity = 14,500 |}} The '''Brisbane Entertainment Centre''' is a multi-purpose [[arena]] located in the [[Brisbane]] suburb of [[Boondall]], [[Queensland]], [[Australia]]. The centre is managed by [[AEG Ogden]]. The arena has an array of [[seating plan]]s which facilitate the comfort of its users, subject to performance. Specific seating plans are usually allocated, depending on the performance and the size of its audience. The general seating arrangements are end stage mode, "in the round" and intimate mode, which only uses half of the arena. The centre also houses a sporting complex and small function rooms which are available to hire for [[wedding reception]] and business functions. The centre has 11,000 tiered seats and a maximum concert capacity of 14,500 making it the largest indoor live entertainment arena in Brisbane and the second largest permanent indoor arena in Australia behind only the 21,000 capacity [[Sydney Super Dome]] (it is smaller than the 14,820 seat [[Rod Laver Arena]] and the 14,856 seat [[Perth Arena]], though both of those venues have a [[retractable roof]]).{{Cite news |url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/entertainment/entertainment-centre-in-worlds-top-20-20121017-27r82.html |title=Entertainment Centre in world's top 20 |author=Marissa Calligeros |accessdate=10 December 2012 |date=17 October 2012 |work=Brisbane Times |publisher=Fairfax Media |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019192659/http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/entertainment/entertainment-centre-in-worlds-top-20-20121017-27r82.html |archivedate=19 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }} It cost $71 million to construct.{{cite book |title=Power and Politics in the City: Brisbane in transition |editor1-first=Janice |editor1-last=Caulfield |editor2-first=John |editor2-last=Wanner |chapter=Local Resource Allocation in the City: Structural-Institutional Power |last=Wanna |first=John |author2=Robyn Davies |year=1995 |publisher=Macmillan Education AU |isbn=0732929997 |page=86 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qjhLdOf9lgwC |accessdate=22 March 2012}} The centre's large audience capacity is mostly used for the staging of [[concerts]] and [[musical theatre]] shows, including [[Whitney Houston]]’s [[Nothing But Love World Tour]], [[One Direction]]'s [[Take Me Home Tour (One Direction)|Take Me Home Tour]], [[Taylor Swift]]'s [[Fearless Tour|Fearless]] and [[Speak Now World Tour|Speak Now]] Tours, [[Shawn Mendes]]' [[Illuminate World Tour]], [[Grease (musical)|Grease]], [[Beauty and the Beast (musical)|Beauty and the Beast]], and [[The Man from Snowy River: Arena Spectacular]]. It has also staged [[ice-skating]] shows, including ''[[Disney On Ice]]''. The Entertainment Centre was also the filming venue for the original Australian series of [[Gladiators (Australian TV series)|Gladiators]] from 1995 to 1997. ==Location== Located in Boondall, just off the Gateway Motorway, patrons can catch a [[Queensland Rail City network]] service to Boondall railway station, on the [[Shorncliffe railway line]], or travel by taxi. There are 4,000 car parking spaces. Buses do not run to the centre even on event nights. ==Brisbane Bullets== From 1986–1997 the BEC was home to former [[National Basketball League Australia|NBL]] team the [[Brisbane Bullets]]. The Bullets won the 1987 NBL championship against the [[Perth Wildcats]], and secured their second NBL championship at this venue as they completed a two-game sweep of the Wildcats 2-0 after winning the first game which was played at the [[Challenge Stadium|Perth Superdome]].[http://www.nbl.com.au/nbl-hq/history/year-by-year-history/80s/1987/ National Basketball League: 1987] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110426192312/http://www.nbl.com.au/nbl-hq/history/year-by-year-history/80s/1987/ |date=26 April 2011 }}. Retrieved on 22 March 2012. In 1987, the Brisbane Bullets won their second NBL championship and their first at the Entertainment Centre with a 2-0 series win over the [[Perth Wildcats]] (the Bullets previous championship win in 1985 was at the [[Chandler Arena|Sleeman Sports Centre]]). In 1990 the Brisbane Bullets hosted games 2 and 3 of the National Basketball League Grand Final series against the Perth Wildcats, setting a new NBL attendance record for the time in Australia of 13,221 for game 2. In 2007, the Brisbane Bullets won their third and last NBL championship when they defeated the [[Melbourne Tigers]] 3-1 in their best of five game series. The Entertainment Centre was used due to a date clash with the Bullets then home, the [[Brisbane Convention & Exhibition Centre]].{{cn|date=May 2013}} The Brisbane Bullets returned to the NBL in [[2016–17 NBL season|2016–17]] and will again play some games at the Brisbane Entertainment Centre.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6CD5A0e2vbY Brisbane Bullets vs Adelaide 36ers highlights - 2016] ==Notable events== The opening event for the centre was on Thursday 20 February 1986, featuring World Champion, British ice skaters, [[Torvill and Dean]]. Ticket prices were Adults $22.90 and Juniors $15.90{{cite web |url=http://www.brisent.com.au/Venue_Information/History.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-07-09 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170716144807/http://www.brisent.com.au/Venue_Information/History.aspx |archivedate=16 July 2017 |df=dmy-all }}, Retrieved on 9 July 2013 [[File:Brisbane-Entertainment-Centre-grounds-1.jpg|thumb|The grounds of the Brisbane Entertainment Centre]] [[File:Brisbane-Entertainment-Centre-grounds-2.jpg|thumb|The grounds of the Brisbane Entertainment Centre]] In 1987, [[Michael Jackson]] performed during his [[Bad (tour)|''Bad'' tour]] for two sold out shows on 27 and 28 November. On the 28th, [[Stevie Wonder]] appeared on stage and sang with Jackson.{{Cite book |last=Campbell |first=Lisa D. |title=Michael Jackson: The King of Pop |edition=1 |publisher=Branden Books |isbn=978-0-8283-1957-7 |year=1993 |page=210}} On 19 November later that year, [[Eric Clapton]] played a sold-out concert at the venue during his [[Journeyman World Tour]] in front of 14,500 people. On 31 January 1998, [[Mariah Carey]] held a concert as part of Butterfly World Tour. On 28 February 2007, Irish vocal pop band [[Westlife]] held a concert for [[The Love Tour]] supporting their album [[The Love Album (Westlife album)|The Love Album]]. On 4 February 2010, [[Taylor Swift]] performed at the Brisbane Entertainment Centre for the first time to 11,334 people. She made an income of $956,505. On 22 February 2010, the singer [[Whitney Houston]] performed her [[Nothing But Love World Tour]] to promo her new CD titled [[I Look To You]] [[Lady Gaga]] performed at the arena as part of her [[Monster Ball Tour]] on March 26-27, 2010. On 6 and 7 March 2012, Taylor Swift performed her [[Speak Now World Tour]]. She made an income of $2,416,030 with the attendance of 19,870 people. On 19–21 October 2013, [[One Direction]] performed for the first time at this venue during the [[Take Me Home Tour (One Direction)|Take Me Home Tour]], with the attendance of 30,831 over the course of 3 nights reeling in a revenue of $2,729,520. On 16 and 17 March 2016, [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] performed at the arena as part of her [[Rebel Heart Tour]]. The second show gained international attention when the singer accidentally exposed the breast of a 17-year-old woman on stage by pulling down her top; Madonna had jokingly responded "Oh sorry, sexual harassment". The incident caused controversy though several publications, where members of the public took to social media to label the incident as an [[assault]].{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/madonna-exposes-fan-at-second-brisbane-show-20160318-gnlt03.html|title=Madonna exposes fan at second Brisbane show|author=Sydney Morning Herald staff|date=18 March 2016|accessdate=19 March 2016|publisher=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160319071428/http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/madonna-exposes-fan-at-second-brisbane-show-20160318-gnlt03.html|archivedate=19 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|url=http://www.people.com/article/madonna-brisbane-concert-breast-expose|title=Madonna Pulls Down Female Fan's Top at Brisbane Concert, Tells Her: 'Oh Sorry, Sexual Harassment'|author=Mizoguchi, Karen|date=18 March 2016|accessdate=19 March 2016|publisher=[[People.com]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160319121904/http://www.people.com/article/madonna-brisbane-concert-breast-expose|archivedate=19 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/madonna-shocks-pulls-down-female-7580421|title=Madonna shocks as she pulls down a female fan's TOP to reveal her bare breast on stage|author=Forrester, Katy|date=18 March 2016|accessdate=19 March 2016|publisher=[[Mirror.co.uk]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160319035159/http://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/madonna-shocks-pulls-down-female-7580421|archivedate=19 March 2016|df=dmy-all}} Despite this, the 17-year-old woman, who was identified as Josephine Georgiou, defended the singer by stating it was "the best time of my life". In spite of having been approached by lawyers offering to represent her, Georgiou also refused to launch legal action against the singer.{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/gossip/la-et-mg-madonna-australia-fan-breast-exposed-onstage-not-offended-20160318-story.html|title=Wardrobe malfunction onstage with Madonna was the 'best moment,' 17-year-old girl says|author=Saad, Nardine|date=18 March 2016|accessdate=19 March 2016|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160319044952/http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/gossip/la-et-mg-madonna-australia-fan-breast-exposed-onstage-not-offended-20160318-story.html|archivedate=19 March 2016|df=dmy-all}} On 25 April 2016, pioneering heavy metal band [[Black Sabbath]] performed their final Australian show at this arena. Supporting act was [[Rival Sons]]. On 12 September 2017, [[Ariana Grande]] performed at this arena for the first time as part of the [[Dangerous Woman Tour]]. On 29 November 2017, [[Shawn Mendes]] performed for a first time at this arena as a part of [[Illuminate World Tour]]. On 28 April 2018, [[Harry Styles]] will perform for a first time at this arena as part of the [[Harry Styles: Live on Tour]]. On 3 June 2018, [[Niall Horan]] will perform for a first time at this arena as a part of [[Flicker World Tour]]. On 30 and 31 July 2018 [[Céline Dion]] will perform at this arena as a part of [[Celine Dion Live 2018]]. This will be the first show of Dion since [[Taking Chances World Tour]] in 10 years. On 28 and 29 September 2018 [[Cher]] will perform at this arena as part of the [[Here We Go Again Tour]]. ==See also== {{Portal|Queensland}} *[[Popular entertainment in Brisbane]] {{-}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category inline}} *[http://www.brisent.com.au Brisbane Entertainment Centre] – Official website *[http://www.thegabba.org.au/content/standard.asp?name=BrisbaneEntertainmentCentre Information about the Brisbane Entertainment Centre]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} by the Queensland Government {{Brisbane Bullets}} {{Brisbane landmarks}} {{NBL Arenas}} [[Category:Music venues in Australia]] [[Category:Netball venues in Australia]] [[Category:Brisbane Bullets]] [[Category:National Basketball League (Australia) venues]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Australia]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Brisbane]] [[Category:Music venues completed in 1986]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1986]] [[Category:Boxing venues in Australia]] [[Category:Sports venues in Brisbane]] [[Category:1986 establishments in Australia]] [[Category:Boondall, Queensland]]

page.title: British Ice Hockey Hall of Fame

revision.text:
The '''British Ice Hockey Hall of Fame''' was founded in 1948 and is the third oldest [[ice hockey]] [[Hall of Fame]] in the world, behind the [[Russian and Soviet Hockey Hall of Fame]] (also founded in 1948) and the [[International Hockey Hall of Fame]] (founded in 1943). The Hall honours individuals who have made important contributions to the sport of hockey in [[United Kingdom|Britain]]. The Hall houses displays and exhibitions of memorabilia depicting significant contributions of players, coaches, referees and other individuals.
The Hall of Fame was founded by the weekly ''Ice Hockey World'' newspaper in 1948. When the newspaper stopped being published in 1958, the Hall of Fame ceased to exist. In 1986, the Hall was re-established by the British Ice Hockey Writers' Association (now called [[Ice Hockey Journalists UK]] (IHJUK)).
A sub-committee of IHJUK meets each year to decide on a list of potential inductees. To be inducted, individuals must have contributed "outstanding service to British ice hockey".
==See also== *[[List of members of the British Ice Hockey Hall of Fame]]
==External links== *[http://www.icehockeyuk.co.uk/hall-of-fame/ British Ice Hockey Hall of Fame] official website
{{Ice hockey halls of fame}} {{British ice hockey}}

revision.text:
{{distinguish|Castelão (Maranhão)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2014}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Castelão | nickname = "Gigante da Boa Vista" | image = [[File:Castelão Stadium.png|330px|Arena Castelão in 2013]] | fullname = Estádio Governador Plácido Castelo | location = [[Fortaleza]], [[Ceará]], Brazil | coordinates = {{coord|3|48|26|S|38|31|21|W|type:landmark_region:BR|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = 1969 | built = 1969–1973 | opened = November 11, 1973 | renovated = 2002 and 2012 | expanded = 1980 | closed = | demolished = | record_attendance = 118,496 | owner = [[Ceará|State of Ceará]] | operator = [[Ceará|State of Ceará]] | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = José Liberal de Castro
Gehard Ernst Borman
Reginaldo Mendes Rangel
Marcílio Dias de Luna
Ivan da Silva Britto | structural engineer = Hugo Alcântara Mota | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants =
[[Fortaleza Esporte Clube|Fortaleza]]
[[Ceará Sporting Club|Ceará]] | suites = | seating_capacity = 63,903{{cite web|url=http://cdn.cbf.com.br/content/201601/20160122182359_0.pdf |title=CNEF - Cadastro Nacional de Estádios de Futebol|date=January 18, 2016 |accessdate=June 6, 2016 |language=Portuguese}} | dimensions = 105 x 68 m }} The '''Estádio Governador Plácido Castelo''', also known as the '''Castelão''' ({{IPA-pt|kasteˈlɐ̃w}}, Portuguese for "Big Castle") or '''Gigante da Boa Vista''', is a football stadium that was inaugurated on November 11, 1973 in [[Fortaleza]], [[Ceará]], Brazil, with a maximum capacity of 63,903 spectators. The stadium is owned by the Ceará state Government, and is the home ground of [[Ceará Sporting Club]] and [[Fortaleza Esporte Clube]]. Its formal name honors Plácido Aderaldo Castelo, who served as the Governor of Ceará from September 12, 1966 to March 15, 1971, and was a leader in getting the stadium built.{{cite book | first = | last = | title = Enciclopédia do Futebol Brasileiro Lance Volume 2 | publisher = Aretê Editorial S/A | location = Rio de Janeiro | year = 2001 | pages = 457–458| isbn = 85-88651-01-7}} ==History== Castelão was constructed from 1969 to 1973 and was inaugurated on November 11 of that year. In May 2000, the Ceará state government started to reform the stadium. The reformations were divided in three stages, and started on May 16, 2001. The first stage consisted in the recovery of the ditches, and of the bleachers junctions, as well as the recovery of the low walls. The second stage of the reformation started on July 20, 2001, and consisted in the recovery and strengthening of the stadium's physical structure. The third stage consisted in the recovery of the electrical, hydraulic, sanitary, and electronic installations. The inaugural match was played on November 11, 1973, when Ceará and Fortaleza drew 0-0. The stadium's first goal was scored on November 18, 1973 by Ceará's Erandy, when Ceará beat [[Esporte Clube Vitória|Vitória]] 1-0.{{cite web|title=Castelão |url=http://mavalem.sites.uol.com.br/ce/Fortaleza1.htm |accessdate=2008-09-13 |publisher=Templos do Futebol |language=Portuguese |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080623200430/http://mavalem.sites.uol.com.br/ce/Fortaleza1.htm |archivedate=June 23, 2008 }} The re-inaugural match was played on March 23, 2002, when the [[Brazil national football team|Brazil national team]] beat the [[Yugoslavia national football team|Yugoslavia national team]] 1-0. The stadium's first goal after the re-inauguration was scored by Brazil's [[Luiz Carlos Bombonato Goulart|Luizão]]. The stadium's attendance record currently stands at 118,496, set on August 27. 1980, when the Brazil national team beat the [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay national team]] 1-0. ==2013 FIFA Confederations Cup== {{clear}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:100%;" |- !Date !Time ([[Time in Brazil#Brasília official time - BRT (UTC-03)|UTC-03]]) !Team #1 !Res. !Team #2 !Round !Attendance |- |June 19, 2013||16:00||{{fb|BRA}} ||style="text-align:center;"|2–0||{{fb|MEX}} ||[[2013 FIFA Confederations Cup Group A|Group A]]||style="text-align:center;"|57,804 |- |June 23, 2013||16:00||{{fb|NGA}} ||style="text-align:center;"|0–3||{{fb|ESP}} ||[[2013 FIFA Confederations Cup Group B|Group B]]||style="text-align:center;"|51,263 |- |June 27, 2013||16:00||{{fb|ESP}} ||style="text-align:center;"|0–0 a.e.t.(Penalties: 7–6)||{{fb|ITA}} ||[[2013 FIFA Confederations Cup knockout stage|Semi-Final]]||style="text-align:center;"|56,083 |} ==2014 FIFA World Cup== Castelão was one of the venues of the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]], which took place in Brazil. The stadium was redeveloped for the tournament; the reconstruction project, by Uruguayan architect [[Héctor Vigliecca]], involved the addition of a larger roof, the construction of an underground car park with 4,200 spaces, and a new lower tier. After the redevelopment, the stadium now has an [[all-seater stadium|all-seater]] capacity of 60,342.{{citation needed|date=February 2013}} The stadium closed on March 31, 2011 for the reconstruction project, which was officially completed in December 2012.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-20753289 |title=Brazil opens first World Cup 2014 stadium |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=December 17, 2012 |accessdate=December 31, 2012}} Castelão was the first of 12 stadiums being built or redeveloped for the 2014 World Cup to be completed. {{clear}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:100%;" |- !Date !Time ([[Time in Brazil#Brasília official time - BRT (UTC-03)|UTC-03]]) !Team #1 !Res. !Team #2 !Round !Attendance |- |June 14, 2014||16:00||{{fb|URU}} ||style="text-align:center;"|1–3||{{fb|CRC}} ||[[2014 FIFA World Cup Group D|Group D]]||style="text-align:center;"|58,679 |- |June 17, 2014||16:00||{{fb|BRA}} ||style="text-align:center;"|0–0||{{fb|MEX}} ||[[2014 FIFA World Cup Group A|Group A]]||style="text-align:center;"|60,342 |- |June 21, 2014||16:00||{{fb|GER}} ||style="text-align:center;"|2–2||{{fb|GHA}} ||[[2014 FIFA World Cup Group G|Group G]]||style="text-align:center;"|59,621 |- |June 24, 2014||17:00||{{fb|GRE}} ||style="text-align:center;"|2–1||{{fb|CIV}} ||[[2014 FIFA World Cup Group C|Group C]]||style="text-align:center;"|59,095 |- |June 29, 2014||13:00||{{fb|NED}} ||style="text-align:center;"|2–1||{{fb|MEX}} ||[[2014 FIFA World Cup knockout stage|Round of 16]]||style="text-align:center;"|58,817 |- |July 4, 2014||17:00||{{fb|BRA}} ||style="text-align:center;"|2–1||{{fb|COL}} ||[[2014 FIFA World Cup knockout stage|Quarter-finals]]||style="text-align:center;"|60,342 |} ==Other events== On July 9, 1980, it was opened in Fortaleza the 10th National Eucharistic Congress. [[Pope John Paul II]] participated in the celebrations of the Congress and the Estádio Castelão received the largest public of its history: 120,000 followers. On this occasion, during Virgílio Távora's government, the stadium was reformed, and the bleachers of the inferior section were concluded. Another religious celebration happened on August 13, 1995. On this occasion the archbishop of Fortaleza Dom Aloísio Lorscheider farewell gathered 50 thousand followers. Several artistic shows were made at the stadium. One of the most outstanding happened on December 10, 1996 when [[Xuxa]] commanded the animation to thousands of children. ==Concerts== [[File:Castelão Stadium, Fortaleza,Brazil 6.jpg|thumb|Castelão in 2009]] {| class = "wikitable sortable" |- !Band/artist !Tour !Attendance !Year !Date |- |[[Iron Maiden]] |''[[The Book of Souls World Tour]]'' |36,000 |2016 |March 24 |- |- |[[Franklin Graham]] |''Festival Of Hope BGEA'' |50,000 |2015 |October 24 |- |- |[[Franklin Graham]] |''Festival Of Hope BGEA'' |45,000 |2015 |October 23 |- |- |[[Franklin Graham]] |''Festival Of Hope BGEA'' |38,000 |2015 |October 22 |- |- |[[Elton John]] |''[[The Diving Board Tour]]'' |18,979 |2014 |February 23 |- |[[Beyoncé]] |''[[The Mrs. Carter Show World Tour]]'' |27,847 |2013 |September 8 |- |[[Paul McCartney]] |''[[Out There! Tour]]'' |48,668 |2013 |May 9 |- |[[Xuxa]] |''Sexto Sentido: O Xou'' |45,000 |1996 |December 10 |- |[[Mamonas Assassinas]] |''Mamonas Assassinas Tour'' |37,000 |1995 |December 22 |- |Menudos |''Menudos Live 1985 Tour'' |70,000 |1985 | |- |} == Galery == File:Castelão Arena (2).jpg| File:Castelão Arena (3).jpg| File:Castelão Arena (6).jpg| File:Castelão Arena (5).jpg| File:Castelão Arena (7).jpg| File:Castelão Arena (4).jpg| File:Fortaleza Arena on March 2014..jpg ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Sister project links|author=no|commons=Category:Estádio_Plácido_Aderaldo_Castelo|wikt=no|b=no|n=no|q=no|s=no|v=no|d=Q47563}} * {{Webarchive |url=https://archive.is/20130627021626/http://arenacastelao.com/site/index.php |title=Official Website}} * [https://www.fifa.com/confederationscup/destination/stadiums/stadium=5025114/index.html FIFA Profile] {{Campeonato Brasileiro Série A venues}} {{Campeonato Brasileiro Série B venues}} {{2014 FIFA World Cup stadiums}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Castelao Ceara}} [[Category:Football venues in Ceará]] [[Category:Sports venues in Ceará]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1973]] [[Category:2014 FIFA World Cup stadiums]] [[Category:2013 FIFA Confederations Cup stadiums]]

{{Chess diagram |tright | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | |kd| | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | |rl| | | | | | | | | |kl| | | |[[White and Black in chess|Black]]'s king is in check by the [[Rook (chess)|rook]]. }}
A '''check''' is a condition in [[chess]], [[shogi]], and [[xiangqi]] that occurs when a player's [[King (chess)|king]] (or general in xiangqi) is under threat of {{chessgloss|capture}} on their opponent's next turn. A king so threatened is said to be ''in check''. A player must get out of check, if possible, by [[Interposing (chess)|interposing]] a [[Piece (chess)|piece]] between the threatening piece and the king, capturing the threatening piece, or moving the king to a square where it is no longer in check. If the player cannot move out of check, the game ends in [[checkmate]] and the player loses. Players cannot make any move that puts their own king in check. {{AN chess|pos=tocleft}}
==Introduction== A check is the result of a move that places the opposing king under an immediate threat of capture by at least one of the player's pieces. Making a move that checks is sometimes called "giving check". If the king is in check and the checked player has no legal move to get out of check, the king is [[checkmate]]d and the player loses.
Under the [[rules of chess|standard rules of chess]], a player may not make any move that places or leaves their king in check. A player may move the king, capture the threatening piece, or [[Block (chess)|block]] the check with another piece.<ref>{{harvcol|Just|Burg|2003|p=27}}, {{harvcol|Polgar|Truong|2005|pp=32,103}}, {{harvcol|Burgess|2009|p=550}}</ref> A king cannot itself directly check the opposing king, since this would place the first king in check as well. A move of the king could expose the opposing king to a [[discovered check]] by another piece, however.
In informal games, it is customary to announce "check" when making a move that puts the opponent's king in check. In formal competitions, however, check is rarely announced.<ref>{{Harvcol|Just|Burg|2003|p=28}}</ref>
In some [[chess variations|variations of chess]], such as [[Losing chess]], a player can move into check. In [[fast chess]], a player is permitted to leave their king in check, which results in them losing the game.
==Getting out of check== {| align="right" border="0" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="0" |-valign="top" | {{Chess diagram |tright | | | | | | | | |kd | | | |pl|xx| | | | | |rl|xx|kl| | | | | | | |xx| | | | |nl| | | | | | | | | | | | | | |bd| | | | | | | | | | | | |rd| | |White is in check. The king can get out of check by three methods. }} | {{Chess diagram |tright | | |kd| | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | |rd| | | | | | | | | | | | | |bd| | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | |pl | | | | | | | |kl |White is in checkmate. The king cannot escape check and White has lost the game. }} |} There may be up to three possible ways to get a king out of a single check on the following move: #''Capturing the checking piece, with either the king or another piece.'' If the checking piece is on a square next to the king, the king can capture the piece if the king does not move into a new check (i.e. if the piece is not protected by another enemy piece). Likewise, a piece that is [[Pin (chess)|pinned]] to the king cannot capture the checking piece if such a move would place the king in check from the pinning piece. #''Moving the king to an adjacent square where it is not in check.'' The king is not allowed to [[castling|castle]] when it is in check. The king may capture an enemy piece in a move to get out of check, as long as the piece is not protected. #''Blocking the check.'' This only works if the checking piece is a [[Queen (chess)|queen]], [[Rook (chess)|rook]], or [[Bishop (chess)|bishop]] and there is at least one empty square in the line between the checking piece and the checked king. Blocking a check is done by moving a piece to one such empty square. (The blocking piece is then [[Pin (chess)|pinned]] to the king by the attacking piece.)<ref>{{harvcol|Polgar|Truong|2005|pp=32,103}}</ref>
In the position in the first diagram, White can get out of check by any of three methods: # Capturing the attacking piece by the move Nxa2. # Moving the king to any unattacked square (marked with "x"); namely, Kd6, Ke5, or Ke7. # Blocking the check by the move Rc4 or Nd5.
If a king is placed in [[double check]], the king must get out of both checks on the following move. Since it is impossible to capture both checking pieces or block both lines of attack in a single move, a double check can be escaped only by moving the king out of check.
If none of these possibilities can get the king out of check, then it is checkmated and the game is lost by the checkmated player. {{clear}}
==Types of checks== A simple and very common type of check is when a piece moves to directly attack the opposing king only by itself. Sometimes such a check is part of a [[chess tactic]] such as a [[Fork (chess)|fork]], a [[Skewer (chess)|skewer]], or a [[discovered attack]] on another piece. In some cases, a check can be used to defend against such tactics.
There are also a few more special types of check: *''[[Discovered check]]''. A discovered check is similar to any other type of discovered attack except that it is a discovered attack on the opposing king. In a discovered check, a piece moves out of the line of attack by another piece so that this other piece (which can be a queen, rook, or bishop) is then checking the opponent's king. The piece that actually moved in the discovered check move could possibly be any type of piece belonging to the same player as the checking piece except queen or the same type of piece administering the check. A discovered check could be a tactic in itself because the piece that moved could attack or otherwise create a threat to another piece on the checked king's side. The opponent has to get out of the discovered check on the following move and may not get a chance to thwart the attack by the other piece that moved. *''[[Double check]]''. A double check is a check from two pieces to the opponent's king in a single move. This happens when a moved piece attacks the king, resulting in a second piece giving check by discovered check. It can also happen, though very rarely, when an ''[[en passant]]'' capture opens two lines of attack simultaneously. In algebraic chess notation, a double check move is sometimes noted with a "++" after the written move in place of the usual "+", although "++" has been used to indicate checkmate (along with "#").<ref>[http://www.fide.com/fide/handbook.html?id=125&view=article FIDE Laws of chess]</ref> A double check cannot be blocked, nor can it be met by capturing one of the checking pieces (unless the king itself makes the capture), because there is check from two directions. *''[[Cross-check]]''. When a check is answered by a check, particularly when this second check is delivered by a piece blocking the first, it is called a ''cross-check''. In fact, a "cross-checkmate" is also possible in that way (that is, to answer a check with a checkmate) but since no such term exists, it would be called cross-check as well. Cross-checks are rather rare in actual gameplay but are a popular theme in [[chess problems]].
==Announcing check and notation== In friendly games, the checking player customarily says "check" when making a checking move. Announcing "check" is not required under the [[rules of chess]] and it is usually not done in formal games. Until the early 20th century a player was expected to announce "check", and some sources of rules even required it {{Harvcol|Hooper|Whyld|1992|p=74}}.
In [[algebraic chess notation]], a checking move is recorded like any other move, except that a "+" is normally written after the move.
In the [[FIDE]] rules for rapid chess, if a player leaves their king in check or commits any other illegal move their opponent can claim a win.<ref>http://www.fide.com/component/handbook/?id=171&view=article (accessed 22 March 2015)</ref>
===Historical=== Less commonly (and obsolete), the warning ''garde'' can be said when a player directly attacks the opponent's [[Queen (chess)|queen]] in a similar way. This was mostly abandoned in the 19th century {{Harvcol|Hooper|Whyld|1992|p=74}}. The same move can be both ''check'' and ''garde'' simultaneously. Before the queen acquired its current move (about 1495) the rook was the most powerful piece. At that time the term ''check-rook'' was used for a move that checked the king and attacked a rook at the same time {{Harvcol|Hooper|Whyld|1992|p=75}}.
==Checking in tactics and strategy== Sometimes checking an opponent provides no benefit to the checking player. This is called a "useless check" and it may even provide the checked opponent with a [[tempo (chess)|tempo]] (move opportunity) to move the king into a safer position {{harvcol|Hooper|Whyld|1992|p=437}}. For example, 1.e4 e6 2.d4 Bb4+? does nothing for Black and in fact causes him to lose a tempo after 3.c3! A check given with the sole intention of delaying an inevitable defeat by one move is referred to as a "spite check", and may be considered somewhat unsporting {{harvcol|Eade|2005|p=65}}.
There are many instances, however, when checking the opponent's king may be a useful tactic or part of a tactic, either in attacking or in defense. Checking is often used in [[combination (chess)|combinations]] with many other tactics or simply to force an opponent into a position where the opposing king can be checkmated, otherwise taken advantage of, or is otherwise worse for the opponent. Some attacks involve numerous checks to force an opponent into a losing position, especially when the king is exposed. An unexpected check in a forced combination or an overlooked cross-check in a planned series of checks may serve as sort of a [[zwischenzug]], foiling the plan.
Some uses of checking: * Repetitive checking to prevent losing a game going poorly (i.e. to [[draw (chess)|draw]] the game by [[perpetual check]]). * Royal [[fork (chess)|fork]] ([[Knight (chess)|knight]] fork of king and queen) or other forks involving the king. * Checks to force an [[Exchange (chess)|exchange]]. * A double check could be especially bad for the opponent since there are likely to be fewer options to get out of check. A double check is often more likely to lead to checkmate or loss of material. * A check might force a king to move so that it cannot [[castling|castle]] later. * Moving a piece to give check can sometimes open a line of attack on another piece. The opponent must escape the check, and therefore cannot (in general) prevent the other piece from being captured ([[discovered attack]]). * Similarly, the piece moved to create a discovered check may attack another enemy piece, leading to the same scenario. * The king may also, by being forced to move out of check, enable the checking piece to capture another piece (an absolute [[skewer (chess)|skewer]]). * A check might force some piece to block it and therefore pose an absolute [[Pin (chess)|pin]] on that piece. * A check might deflect the king from protecting some other piece (particularly in an [[chess endgame|endgame]], to capture opponent's pawns). * A check could sometimes be used to foil an opponent's trap which would otherwise lead to loss of material. For example, if an opponent forks two of a player's pieces, the attacked player may be able to move one of the forked pieces to check the opponent's king requiring the opponent to save it on his/her next move, thus allowing the player to then move the other forked piece to also save it from attack.
==History== In early Sanskrit chess (c. 500–700) the king could be {{chessgloss|captured}} and this ended the game. The Persians (c. 700–800) introduced the idea of warning that the king was under attack (announcing ''check'' in modern terminology). This was done to avoid the early and accidental end of a game. Later the Persians added the additional rule that a king could not be moved into check or left in check. As a result, the king could not be captured {{harvcol|Davidson|1949|p=22}}.
In this usage, the words "check" and "chess" come via Arabic from Persian ''shāh'', meaning "king"<ref>[http://www.goddesschess.com/chessays/shahmatjan.html "The King Is not Dead After All! The Real Meaning of Shah Mat or the Lesson of the Commode"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513054140/http://www.goddesschess.com/chessays/shahmatjan.html |date=May 13, 2008 }}, Jan Newton, GoddessChess.com, September 2003</ref> or "monarch" {{harvcol|Murray|2012|p=159}}.
==See also== * [[Go terms#Atari+(.E5.BD.93.E3.81.9F.E3.82.8A?)|Atari]] in [[Game of Go]] * [[Checkmate]] * [[Rules of chess]]

[[Category:Chess rules]] [[Category:Chess terminology]]

{{Infobox sport | image = Circle rules football 6-20-12.jpg | imagesize = 300px | caption = A game of circle rules football | union = Circle Rules Federation | nickname = Circle rules, CRF | first = 2006, [[New York City|New York]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | registered = | contact = Contact | team = 6 | mgender = Coed | category = [[Team sport]], [[ball game|ball sport]] | ball = | olympic = }} '''Circle rules football''', commonly referred to as '''circle rules''', is a [[team sport|sport]] played between two teams of six with a large spherical ball similar to a [[exercise ball|stability ball]]. Invented in [[New York City]] in 2006,<ref>[https://www.wired.com/playbook/2011/05/circle-rules-football/ Circle Rules Football: Experimental Theater Meets Sports]</ref> the sport is currently played in cities across the [[United States]], as well as in several international locations.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/17/fashion/17games.html?pagewanted=1 With Games They Invent, Artists Unleash the Athlete Within]</ref><ref>[http://www.nyc.gov/html/nycmg/nyctvod/html/home/lnyc103.html Lunch NYC: From the Playground to the Park]</ref>
The game is played on a circular [[playing field|field]] with a central [[goal (sport)|goal]]. The goal has no [[net (device)|net]], as the two teams score through the goal from opposing directions. Around the goal is a circular area called the “key,” which only the teams’ [[goalkeeper|goalies]] may enter. Players outside the key may touch the ball with any part of their bodies, allowing them to [[dribbling|dribble]], [[kick (football)|kick]], roll, carry, and throw the ball; however, they may not hold the ball in any way that restricts its movement. The team that scores the most goals by the end of the match wins.
==Gameplay== Each team consists of six players (excluding substitutes), one of whom is the goalkeeper. Teams may be coed, though they are not required to be. Two [[referee]]s are on the field at all times; one watches over the key to call key violations and ensure the safety of the goalies, while the other moves freely around the field.
An official game consists of four fifteen-minute periods. Prior to the start of the game, a representative from each team participates in a "down-up." The two players stand opposite each other; on the referee's signal, they race to touch both [[scapula|shoulder blades]] to the ground and return to a stationary standing position. As in a [[coin flipping|coin toss]], the winner of the down-up gets to choose which direction his team will score and whether his team will [[kick-off (association football)|kick off]] or receive the ball at the start of the match.
The team that is kicking off gathers inside the key, while the other team takes up their positions outside. After the kick off, the kicking team must wait inside the key until a member of the other team has touched the ball; at this point the kicking team is released from the key, and no players except the goalies may reenter it until a goal has been scored. After each goal, the scoring team gathers inside the key and repeats this procedure.
Goals are scored by putting the ball through the goalposts in a team's designated direction. Each goal is worth one [[score (sport)|point]]. Outside the key, players may touch the ball with any part of their body; however, they cannot hold the ball with two hands or hold it against their body in a way that restricts the ball's movement. Players are free to dribble, kick, roll, carry, throw, and strike the ball, and they may move it in any direction around the field.
Physical contact between players on the field is limited. Incidental contact, as well as contact that is the result of a movement that causes contact with the ball before contact with another player, is generally not [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalized]]. The referees' discretion plays a large role in determining the type and intensity of contact that is allowed on the field.
Inside the key, the goalies attempt to defend their own side of the goal, while allowing their team to score through from the opposite direction. Goalies have [[contact sport|full contact]] with each other, allowing them to [[grappling|grapple]]; however, dangerous moves such as [[strike (attack)|striking]] and contact above the neck are forbidden. Goalies may leave the key to pursue the ball, but they may not have contact with each other outside the key. Goalies may not score for their own teams.
The team with the most goals at the end of the match wins. In the event of a [[tie (draw)|tie]], two five-minute halves of [[overtime (sports)|overtime]] are played.
===Field and equipment=== The game is generally played on a circular field of [[grass]] or [[artificial turf]], though it can also be played on other surfaces, including [[road surface|pavement]] and [[sand]]. The field is 50 meters in diameter. The goal (four meters wide and three meters high) sits in the center of the field, surrounded by a circular area called the key (8 meters in diameter).
The goalposts are typically constructed of 3/4 inch [[Polyvinyl chloride|PVC piping]], a common material found in most hardware stores.
The spherical ball (55 cm in diameter), made of a soft [[Elastomer|elastic]], closely resembles a stability ball.
===Penalties=== The most common penalties are known as "key violations." Any non-goalkeeper who sets foot inside the key (at any time other than kickoff) receives a 30-second suspension from the game without a replacement. If a non-goalkeeper touches the ball while inside the key, the suspension is extended to 60 seconds. Any player who receives three key violations in one game will be suspended from the game for five minutes without a replacement.
Contact violations on the field are similar to soccer or basketball. Inadvertent violations result in a direct kick for the opposing team. Flagrant contact violations result in a 60-second ejection of the offending player and a direct kick. Malicious contact violations result in ejection from the game without replacement. Three violations within a game result in the player being ejected for the remainder of the game, however, they may be replaced after any ejection penalties if the final violation was not malicious.
A penalty may also be called on a player for holding the ball. The penalty for holding is an [[indirect free kick]] for the opposing team from the spot of the violation.
==History== Circle rules football was created by Gregory Manley in 2006 as a senior [[thesis]] project for the Experimental Theater Wing, a division of [[New York University]]'s [[Tisch School of the Arts]].<ref>[http://www.nypress.com/article-19224-forget-pills-take-pilates.html Forget Pills, Take Pilates]</ref><ref>[http://www.good.is/shows/the-wild-frontier-of-sports The Wild Frontier of Sports: Circle Rules Football] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090415084806/http://www.good.is/shows/the-wild-frontier-of-sports |date=2009-04-15 }}</ref> The project aimed to highlight the similarities between [[drama]] and [[athletics (U.S.)|athletics]], demonstrating that “everything inherent in theater is inherent in sports.”<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/17/fashion/17games.html?pagewanted=1 With Games They Invent, Artists Unleash the Athlete Within]</ref>
The game has been played regularly in [[Brooklyn]]'s [[Prospect Park (Brooklyn)|Prospect Park]] since its inception. In the spring of 2009, [http://circlerulesfederation.com/ Circle Rules Federation] began running an official competitive [[sports league|league]] in Brooklyn.<ref>[http://www.wellesleynewsonline.com/sports/new-version-of-football-sweeps-college-campus-1.2110693 New version of football sweeps college campus] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111229232054/http://www.wellesleynewsonline.com/sports/new-version-of-football-sweeps-college-campus-1.2110693 |date=2011-12-29 }}</ref> The first championship title was won by The Flying Mordecais.
Also in 2009, circle rules football was featured in the [http://www.comeoutandplay.org/ Come Out & Play Festival], where it won the "Most Original Sport" and "Best in Festival" awards;<ref>[http://www.theduquesneduke.com/obscure-to-the-extreme-1.2571203 Obscure to the Extreme]</ref> it was also featured at [https://archive.is/20130112223523/http://igfest.org/ igfest] 2009, where it was named "Best in Festival" and "Most Likely to be Played Again."<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/eugene-michael-santiago/circle-rules-football_b_324456.html Circle Rules Football — The Road Ahead]</ref>
Official league play resumed in Brooklyn in 2010, and The Flying Mordecais successfully defended their title. In both the 2011 and 2012 seasons, upstart team The Rebel Rousers went undefeated and claimed the championship.
==Variations== In casual matches, a slightly pared down version of the game, known as "small rules," is often played. Small rules is played without goalies, and the width of the goal and the key are reduced to two and six meters, respectively. In this version of the game, players may enter the key, but they still may not touch the ball inside the area—unless their last point of contact with the ground was outside the key (as in the case of a jump or dive). Small rules is typically played with four members per team on the field at a time.
Since fall 2007, an event called the Harvest Tournament has been held annually. For this [[tournament]], a unique 3-on-3 version of small rules is played. The sixth Harvest Tournament took place in Prospect Park on Saturday, October 20, 2012.
In March 2010, an indoor variation of circle rules football was introduced in London.<ref>[http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/lifestyle/article-23879961-circle-rules-football---a-whole-new-ball-game.do Circle Rules Football - a whole new ball game]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://circlerulesfederation.com/ Circle Rules Federation] * [http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/video?id=8851645 Feature on Good Morning America] * [http://espn.go.com/espn/page2/index?id=6253704 Feature on ESPN's SportsNation]

revision.text:
{{for|the hall stadium in Germany|O2 World Hamburg}} {{Infobox_Stadium | stadium_name = Color Line Stadion | image = [[File:Color Line stadion.jpg|center|300px]] | location = [[Ålesund]], [[Norway]] | broke_ground = | opened = 16 April 2005 | owner = [[Aalesunds FK]] | operator = Aalesunds FK | surface = [[Artificial turf]] | construction_cost = [[Norwegian krone|NOK]] 160 million | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Aalesunds FK]] (2005–)
[[FK Fortuna Ålesund]] (2009–) | seating_capacity = 10,778 ([[association football|Football]]) }} '''Color Line Stadion''' is an [[association football]] [[stadium]] in [[Ålesund]], [[Norway]], and the home of [[Norwegian Premier League]] side [[Aalesunds FK]]. It was inaugurated in April 2005 and cost [[Norwegian krone|NOK]] 160 million to build. It is referred to as '''Aalesund Stadion''' by [[UEFA]].{{cite web |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2013/clubs/club=82819/matches/index.html |title=UEFA Europa League 2012/13 – Aalesunds FK |publisher=UEFA |accessdate=27 July 2012}} It was the first top-level stadium in Norway to feature [[artificial turf]], which was at the time a highly debated issue. When Aalesund opened the stadium, businessman Olav Nils Sunde donated a statue to the club, which was erected in front of the stadium. Whilst Sunde denied it, the statue bore a very strong resemblance to former Aalesund player [[John Arne Riise]]. In 2007, when Riise played in the Champions League Final, a Norwegian commentator demanded the statue officially carry his name. Riise himself has said, "[The name change] is not for me to decide. Everyone sees who it is, and I know that it was made for me."{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/jan/11/the-knowledge-footballers-degrees|title=Which footballers have degrees?|publisher=The Guardian|date=11 January 2012|accessdate=12 January 2012}} Since 2009 it has also hosted the home games of the [[Toppserien|Norwegian Women's Premier League]] side [[Fortuna Ålesund]]. The venue has hosted one [[Norway national under-21 football team]] match, playing 1–3 against [[Cyprus national under-21 football team|Cyprus]] on 3 September 2010.{{cite web |url=http://www.fotball.no/System-pages/TabellTermin/?tournamentId=39901 |title=Norge Menn U21 |publisher=[[Football Association of Norway]] |language=Norwegian |archivedate=26 November 2011 |accessdate=26 November 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63UG3Ayfy?url=http://www.fotball.no/System-pages/TabellTermin/?tournamentId=39901 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In a 2012 survey carried out by the [[Norwegian Players' Association]] among away-team captains, Color Line Stadion was ranked eleventh amongst league stadiums, with a score of 2.87 on a scale from one to five.{{cite news|url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/nrk_trondelag/1.8836297 |title=Lerkendal nest beste fotballbane |publisher=[[Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=28 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CYl4tTGG?url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/nrk_trondelag/1.8836297 |language=Norwegian |archivedate=30 November 2012 |accessdate=30 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ==Facts== [[File:Stormen.JPG|thumb|Stormen Supporters]] [[File:Alesund East.JPG|thumb|South East Stand]] *Capacity: 10,778 (9,598 seated). *Record attendance: 10,903 (vs [[Hamarkameratene]], 2005). *The first match Aafk played on Color Line Stadium was against Odd Grenland. Aalesund won the match. *Outside the stadium is a statue of "the Football Player", modeled after [[John Arne Riise]]. ==Attendance== {|class="wikitable" | width=40px | | [[Norwegian Premier League]] |- ! '''Colpbol''' is a [[team sport]] invented in 2000 by [[Valencia]]n physical education teacher Juanjo Bendicho. Colpbol is characterized by its great dynamism, integration and egalitarianism, with all team members having equal importance, and with mixed gender teams the rule rather than the exception. The people who play this sport use “lechita de la chota”
Colpbol is similar to [[Valencian pilota]] and [[handball]] (in that players strike the ball by hand) as well as [[futsal]] (in terms of size of the playing field, teams and goals).
Since its invention, the popularity of colpbol has spread from Valencia to the rest of Spain and to some countries in [[South America]]. There is a youth colpbol league in Spain with more than 3000 participants.
== External links == * {{official|http://www.colpbol.es}} * {{cite web |url=http://apecva.es/entrevistas/200-entrevista-juanjo-bendicho-colpbol |title=Entrevista Juanjo Bendicho, creador del Colpbol |trans-title=Intervew with Juanjo Bendicho, inventor of Colpbol |work=Associaó de Psicología del deporte de la Communitat Valenciana |date=13 May 2010 }} * [http://www.edu.gva.es/eva/val/programas_exp.htm Conselleria de Educación-Generalitat Valenciana] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130828171019/http://www.nostresport.com/portada/Portada/muestraAtemporal.html?id=174 Reportaje en web Nostresport] * [http://www.lasprovincias.es/v/20110128/deportes/mas-deportes/presentado-libro-colpbol-deporte-20110128.html Periódico Las Provincias-presentación libro sobre el Colpbol] * [http://www.elperiodic.com/pvalencia/noticias/74788_colpbol-cuenta-balon-oficial.html Presentación balón reglamentario] [[Category:Team sports]] [[Category:Ball games]]
