revision.text:
{{Infobox award | name = Coupe Deutsch de la Meurthe | image = | imagesize = 180px | caption = | description = Fastest time over a measured distance (time trial) | presenter = Aéro-Club de France | country = International | reward = | year = 1909 | year2 = 1936 | website = }}
The '''Coupe Deutsch de la Meurthe''' was an international aeronautical speed competition instituted on 25 August 1909 by the French oil magnate [[Henry Deutsch de la Meurthe]]. The race was reinstated three times through the years at the initiative of the [[Aéro-Club de France]], and later by Deutsch de la Meurthe's widow Suzanne.
==First Coupe Deutsch de la Meurthe== Announced in 1906, the first Deutsch de la Meurthe competition was a speed trial intended for all powered aircraft over a distance of 200 kilometres, to be flown as an outward leg of 100 km followed by a return to the starting point.<ref>[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6551284g/f7.image.r=Deutsch%20de%20la%20Meurthe Bulletin Officiel de l'Aėro-Club de France] [[l'Aėrophile]], March 1906, p.71</ref> The flight had to be made between 1 March and 31 October, and the performance was recognized only if the previous best performance was surpassed by at least 10%. A bonus of 20,000 [[French franc|francs]] was awarded each year for the best performance that had remained unsurpassed for eight months. The Coupe (cup), an objet d'art valued at 10,000 francs, was to be given to the first aircraft builder who won three consecutive competitions.<ref name=flight1919>{{cite |journal=Flight |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1919/1919%20-%201366.html |title=Coupe Henry Deutsch de l a Meurthe |volume=XI |number=564|date=16 October 1919 |page= 1368}}</ref> ===1912 competition=== Despite the substantial prize being offered, it took six years to attract participants. On 12 April 1912, [[Maurice Tabuteau]] piloting a 50 hp [[Gnome et Rhône|Gnome]]-powered [[Morane-Saulnier]] monoplane flew the circuit in 1 h 47 min 48 s, despite persistent navigation problems caused by fog. On 1 May 1912 Parisian Emmanuel Hélen completed the course at {{convert|119.532|kph|mph|abbr=on}} flying a 70 hp Gnome-powered [[Nieuport]] monoplane. Since no other pilot bettered this performance by more than 10% before 31 October 1912, Hélen became the first holder of the Coupe.<ref>[https://www.flightglobal.com/flightpdfarchive/view/1921/1921%20-%200317.html Flight, 5 May 1921, p. 317]</ref>
===1913 competition=== On 27 October 1913 [[Eugène Gilbert]] gained first place in the second competition for the Coupe, covering the course at an average speed of {{convert|154.38|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} in a 160 h.p. Gnome-powered [[Deperdussin Monocoque]].
===1919/1920 competition=== [[File:Nieuport-Delage 29V racer.jpg|thumb|Nieuport-Delage NiD.29V racer]] The competition was interrupted by the [[World War I|First World War]], but on 13 October 1919 it resumed using the same course, but the competition was now open for the entire year, and the trophy would be definitely kept by the first participant whose time remained unbeaten for eight consecutive months.<ref>[https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1919/1919%20-%201390.html Coupe Deutsch de la Meurthe] ''Flight'' 23 October 1919</ref> Four aeroplanes participated in this trial: a 180 hp [[Hispano-Suiza]]-powered [[Gourdou-Leseurre]] monoplane piloted by Rost, a 300 hp Hispano-Suiza-powered [[Société Pour L'Aviation et ses Dérivés|SPAD]]-Herbemont piloted by [[Joseph Sadi-Lecointe]], a 300 hp Hispano-Suiza-powered Nieuport biplane piloted by [[Bernard Barny de Romanet]], and a 180 hp Le Rhöne-powered Nieuport monoplane designed by engineer Mary, and flown by the Danish pilot [[Leth Jensen]]. Taking off on 13 October 1919, Jensen flew the circuit at an average speed of 200.001 km/h (57 minutes). The next day, Rost reached an average speed of 210 km/h while de Romanet had an aircraft failure. On 15 October, Sadi-Lecointe flew a first circuit at 223 km/h, and then a second lap at 246.9 km/h and thus became the title holder. On 21 October 1919, de Romanet reached an average speed of 268.631 km/h which was insufficient to be homologated, because this performance was less than 110% of Sadi-Lecointe's performance. He followed it the next day with an average speed of 285.600 km/h which did count. <ref>[https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1919/1919%20-%201420.html "The Coupe Deutsch"] ''Flight'' 30 October 1919 p1422</ref> Bad weather then stopped the competition, which was resumed just three months later. On 3 January 1920, Sadi-Lecointe, who had in the meanwhile had left [[Blériot-SPAD]] for Nieuport, reached {{convert|266.314|km/h|abbr=on}}<ref>"The Deutsch Cup Contest" ''Flight'' 8 January 1920 p56</ref> with a Hispano-engined [[Nieuport-Delage NiD 29]]V. On 3 August 1920, he became the holder of the Coupe Deutsch de la Meurthe, his performance having remained unbeaten.
==Second Coupe Deutsch de la Meurthe== In 1920, following the ending of the [[Gordon Bennett Trophy (aeroplanes)|Gordon Bennett Trophy]] competition due to a third consecutive French victory, the Aéro-Club de France decided to organize a new competition to replace it. This was named ''Coupe Deutsch de la Meurthe'' to honour [[Henry Deutsch de la Meurthe]], who had died on 24 November 1919; the competition was funded by his family.
It remained a speed competition, but was now to be held on a given date. The competition was to be held as 3 laps of a 100 km (62 mi) circuit, with its start at [[Étampes]] and a turn made at la Marmogne farm at [[Gidy]]. The competition was open for three years and was international, with each country allowed three entrants. A sum of 60,000 francs was to be awarded each year for the best performance, and a cup valued at 20,000 francs given to the winner. In the case of the cup being won outright before the end of the competition, the winner would also received the remaining prize money<ref>{{cite |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/flightpdfarchive/view/1921/1921%20-%200327.html |title=Coupe Henry Deutsch de la Meurthe |journal=Flight |date=12 May 1921 |page=327 |format=pdf |number=645 |volume=XIII)}}</ref>
===1921 competition=== [[File:Nieuport-Delage Sesquiplan.jpg|thumb|Nieuport NiD.41 Sesquiplan]] There were seven participants in this race, which was held on 1 October. No eliminating heats were needed to select from the five French pilot entrants, since Count [[Bernard Barny de Romanet|Bernard de Romanet]] died when the wing fabric of his Lumière-De Monge monoplane<ref group=note>The aircraft could be configured as either a biplane or a monoplane.</ref> detached at high speed during the elimination trials on 23 September, and at the last moment [[Hanriot (aircraft company)|Hanriot]] withdrew their entrant, the Hanriot HD.22. This was a metal monoplane with retractable landing gear expressly built for the race, and which had been intended to be piloted by Rost. Nieuport entered two [[Nieuport-Delage NiD 29|Nieuport NiD.29V]]s piloted by Sadi-Lecointe and Ferdinand Lasne, and a [[Nieuport-Delage Sesquiplan|NiD.41 Sesquiplan]] was entrusted to Georges Kirsch. A 700 hp Fiat-powered [[Fiat Aviazione|Fiat]] biplane piloted by [[Francesco Brack Papa]] represented Italy, and British pilot Herbert James flew a 450 hp [[Napier Lion]]-powered [[Nieuport Nighthawk|Gloster Mars I]] (G-EAXZ).<ref name=flight1921>[https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1921/1921%20-%200650.html The Coupe de Deutsch de la Meurthe] ''Flight'', 29 September 1921, pp. 650-651]</ref><ref>Lewis 1971, pp. 119-120</ref> A broken propeller forced Sadi-Lecointe to make a forced landing in a beet field at Cernonville, injuring an eye and both legs in the process. The wing fabric of James' aeroplane was torn away, and he had to make a forced landing. Brach Papa established a new Italian speed record, but the engine exploded before the finish. Thus, only two Nieuport pilots were left to finish the race, Georges Kirsch winning with a speed of 282.75 km/h (a new world speed record for a distance of 300 km); Fernand Lasne's speed was 259.03 km/h.{{cn|date=September 2015}}
===1922 competition=== The 1921 circuit remained unchanged for the 1922 competition, which was held on 30 September. Nieuport-Astra<ref group=note>Nieuport having taken over the [[Société Astra]] by this point</ref> entered a Nieuport NiD.29V piloted by Lasne and the sesquiplane piloted by Sadi-Lecointe, [[Jean Casale]] was piloting a Blériot-SPAD S.58, a design based on the [[Blériot-SPAD S.41|S.41 fighter]]. Fiat and Gloster were presenting the same machines and pilots as the preceding year. Assigned to their factory pilot Berthelin, who was new to this competition, the NiD.41 was retired at the last moment. The [[tailless aircraft|tailless]] Simplex aircraft which was supposed to be piloted by [[Georges Madon]] had an accident during its tests, and [[Charles Nungesser]] was absent.<ref name=flight1922>{{cite |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/flightpdfarchive/view/1922/1922%20-%200573.html |title=The race for the Coupe Deutsch de la Meurthe |journal= Flight |date=5 October 1922 |pages=573-576}}</ref><ref>Lewis 1971, p. 129</ref> In his Nieuport sesquiplane named ''Eugène Gilbert'' (race number 5), Sadi-Lecointe covered the first 100 km at an average speed of 325 km/h (a new closed circuit speed record), but a spark plug popped out of its cylinder and passed through the engine cowling as he was turning around the airport pylon. The pilot was therefore forced to land, and the airplane hit a gutter which turned the aircraft on its back without injuring the pilot. James lost his maps during his flight and unable to find the turning point returned to the start. Jean Casale's SPAD S.58 ''Louis Blériot'' (race no.3) was victim of a radiator leak, and made a forced landing at Étampes and was unable to finish the race, as was also the case for Brack-Papa's [[Fiat B.R.|Fiat R.700]] which had a fuel pump failure.{{cn|date=September 2015}} The first lap made by the Italian pilot at 288 km/h (179 mph) was not homologated since the aircraft had flown behind the time-keepers at the starting point, but he was offered a second attempt. Brack-Papa started a second time but retired when he realized he would not be able to beat Lasne, ) who won the competition with an average speed of 289.90 km/h.<ref name=flight1922/>
==Third Coupe Deutsch de la Meurthe== In 1931 Suzanne Deutsch de la Meurthe initiated a new competition for the Coupe, which was contested for the first time on 29 May 1933. The trial was to be run in two 1,000 km stages separated by a 90 minutes refuelling stop, and was limited to aircraft with an engine capacity of less than eight litres. The starting point of the race was still at Étampes. Suzanne Deutsch de la Meurthe was offering one million Francs, and the Ministère de l'Air (Air Ministry) offered another three million.<ref>[https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1932/1932%20-%200422.html Flight, 6 May 1932, p. 390]</ref> ===1933 competition=== [[File:Potez 53 Musee du Bourget P1010709.JPG|thumb|A Potez 53]] On 24 May 1933 Captain [[Ludovic Arrachart]] was killed when his [[Caudron C.362|Caudron C.360]] (race no.11) crashed due to engine failure at Maisons near [[Chartres]] while he was training for the competition.<ref name>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k65535525/f6.image.r=caudron|date=June 1933|page=166|title=La Coupe Deutsch de la Meurthe}}</ref> The event was won by Georges Détré flying a [[Potez 53]] powered by a Potez 9B radial engine developing barely 310 hp at full power at a speed of {{convert|322.81|kph|mph}}, beating Raymond Delmotte's Caudron C.362 (race no.6) with a speed of {{convert|291.12|kph|mph}}, and also beating the only foreign competitor, [[Nick Comper]] flying [[Comper Swift]] ''G-ABWW'' {{convert|239.58|kph|mph}}.<ref>Lewis 1971, p.251</ref> A third French competitor, test pilot Lemoine also flying a Potez 53, was forced to abandon the race.<ref name=flight1934-510>[https://www.flightglobal.com/flightpdfarchive/view/1934/1934%20-%200510.html Flight, 24 May 1934, pp. 510-511]</ref>
===1934 competition=== [[File:Caudron 460 Le Bourget 2009.jpg|thumb|A Caudron C.460 replica]] [[File:GMars.jpg|thumb|Gloster Mars I (G-EAXZ)]] On 27 May 1934, the race was a duel between the Caudron pilots, the [[Caudron]] firm presenting two racing aircraft designed by [[Marcel Riffard]]. [[Maurice Arnoux]] won with a C.450 at a speed of 388.97 km/h overtaking Louis Massotte's [[Régnier Motor Company|Regnier]]-engined (and sponsored) C.366 (360.72 km/h) and Albert Monville's Renault-engined [[Caudron C.460]] (341.04 km/h). Nick Comper flew the [[Comper Streak]] (G-ACNC), but retired on the 6th lap of the afternoon session as problem with the undercarriage limited his speed. Georges Detre flying a [[Potez 53]]-2 retired after problems with his engine oil supply. The [[Potez 53]]-3 had problems with its variable pitch propeller and was unable to start for the second section,<ref>Lewis 1971, p. 259</ref><ref name=flight1934-510/><ref>[https://www.flightglobal.com/flightpdfarchive/view/1933/1933%20-%200976.html Flight, 9 Nov 1933, p. 976]</ref><ref>[https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1934/1934%20-%200480.html Flight, 17 May 1934, pp. 476, 480-481]</ref><ref>[https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1934/1934%20-%200531.html Flight, 31 May 1934, pp. 531-532]</ref>
===1935 competition=== The 1935 race was arguably the most exciting{{cn|date=September 2015}} competition of them all, and was the consecration of the Caudron-Renault racers. Eight pilots were registered for this event, but the [[Nennig C-3]] (race no.4) of [[Guy Bart]] was not ready, and the Régnier Martinet, a modified Caudron C.366, (race no.2) was damaged during its tests. Two Caudron C.560s were supposed to participate (race no.1 and 3), but were not ready. They were thus replaced by a [[Caudron C.430]] and a C.450 with the same race numbers.<ref name=flight1935>[https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1935/1935%20-%201324.html "A Family Affair"] ''Flight'', 30 May 1935, p. 600</ref>
The course was over 100 km (62 miles), from [[Etampes]] aerodrome to [[Chartres]] [[Boncé|Bonce]] and back. The race itself was in two stages, each of 1,000 km (625 miles).
Charles Franco was the first to take off in Caudron C.430 (race no.1), but abandoned the race on the fourth lap as he was clearly out-classed by the other aircraft. It was followed by the Caudron C.460s of [[Yves Lacombe]] (race no.5), [[Raymond Delmotte]] (Caudron's chief pilot) (race no.8 ), and [[Maurice Arnoux]] (race no.6) respectively, this last entrant having to quit the race after seven laps, having run out of oil after a high-speed lap at {{convert|469|km/h|abbr=on}}. [[Albert Monville]]'s Caudron C.450 (race no.3) was the last to take off. Only three aircraft qualified for the second part of the race, which was held during rain showers. Raymond Delmotte won, ahead of Yves Lacombe and Maurice Arnoux, flying the aircraft previously flown by Albert Monville .<ref name=flight1935/>
==Fourth Coupe Deutsch de la Meurthe== On 13 September 1936, a last competition was organized, in which two [[Caudron C.461]]s, one Caudron C.450 and two [[Caudron C.560]]s took part. Yves Lacombe won this race with a speed of only {{convert|389.462|km/h|abbr=on}}, overtaking Maurice Arnoux timed at {{convert|369.59|km/h|abbr=on}}, a performance barely superior to what had been established in 1934, probably because of bad engine tuning in a competition presenting no real challenge for the engine and aircraft manufacturers.<ref>[https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1936/1936%20-%202782.html ''Flight'', 15 October 1936, p. 387]</ref>{{failed verification|reason=source does not mention anything save Lacombe won|date=September 2015}}
==Footnotes== {{reflist |group=note}} ==Notes== {{reflist|2}}

Éditions Lela Presse {{ISBN|2-914017-08-1}} *Käsmann, Ferdinand C. W. 1990. ''World speed record aircraft, the fastest piston-engined landplanes since 1903''. Docavia n° 43, Éditions Larivière {{ISBN|2 90705 128 8}} [[Category:20th-century awards]] [[Category:Air races]] [[Category:Aviation awards]] [[Category:Sports trophies and awards]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2018}} {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | header = "Hamptons Five" | header_align = left/right/center | header_background = | footer = | footer_align = left/right/center | footer_background = | width = | image1 = Stephen Curry 2016 (cropped).jpg | width1 = 149 | caption1 = [[Stephen Curry]] | image2 = Klay Thompson (cropped).jpg | width2 = 153 | caption2 = [[Klay Thompson]] | image3 = Andre Iguodala 2016 (cropped).jpg | width3 = 185 | caption3 = [[Andre Iguodala]] | image4 = Golden State Warriors Small Forward Kevin Durant (cropped).jpg | width4 = 147 | caption4 = [[Kevin Durant]] | image5 = Draymond Green (33053301711) (cropped).jpg | width5 = 156 | caption5 = [[Draymond Green]] }} The '''Death Lineup''' is a group of smaller [[basketball]] players on the [[Golden State Warriors]] of the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA). Developed under head coach [[Steve Kerr]], it began during their 2014–15 run that led to an [[NBA championship]]. Unlike typical [[small ball (basketball)|small-ball]] units, this Warriors lineup is versatile enough to defend larger opponents, while also aiming to create mismatches on offense with their shooting and playmaking skills.<ref name=tjarks_09062016>{{cite news|last=Tjarks|first=Jonathan|title=The NBA’s New Lineups of Death|date=September 6, 2016|work=The Ringer|url=https://theringer.com/the-nbas-new-lineups-of-death-7e52303954a1|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=https%3A%2F%2Ftheringer.com%2Fthe-nbas-new-lineups-of-death-7e52303954a1&date=2017-06-10|archivedate=June 10, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name=slater_05152016>{{cite news|last=Slater|first=Anthony|title=A clash of styles: The Thunder's big lineup against the Warriors' small-ball unit|date=May 15, 2016|newspaper=The Oklahoman|url=http://newsok.com/article/5498376|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnewsok.com%2Farticle%2F5498376&date=2017-06-10|archivedate=June 10, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name=dubin_03072018>{{cite news|last=Dubin|first=Jared|title=Golden State's Death Lineup Has Been DOA on Defense|date=March 7, 2018|work=Vice Sports|url=https://sports.vice.com/en_us/article/437ead/golden-states-death-lineup-has-been-doa-on-defense|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180313130130/https://sports.vice.com/en_us/article/437ead/golden-states-death-lineup-has-been-doa-on-defense|archivedate=March 13, 2018|deadurl=no}}</ref>
The lineup features the [[Splash Brothers]], a [[Three-point field goal|three-point shooting]] backcourt consisting of two-time [[NBA Most Valuable Player Award|NBA MVP]] [[Stephen Curry]], and perennial two-way All-Star [[Klay Thompson]]. It also features versatile defender [[Andre Iguodala]] on the [[Swingman|wing]] alongside scorer [[Kevin Durant]], and 2016–17 [[NBA Defensive Player of the Year Award|Defensive Player of the Year]] [[Draymond Green]] at [[Center (basketball)|center]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/warriors-death-lineup-game-5-finals-2017-6|title=The Warriors waited until the right moment to unleash their greatest weapon, and the Cavs had no answer|work=Business Insider|access-date=August 6, 2017|language=en}}</ref> Green's defensive versatility has been described as the "key" that allows the lineup to be so effective; although his natural position is [[Power forward (basketball)|power forward]], he is able to play as an undersized center in lieu of a traditional center who might be slower or lack the playmaking and shooting abilities of Green.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.warriorsworld.net/2016/02/03/draymond-green-drives-the-golden-state-machine/|title=How Draymond Green Drives the Golden State Machine – Warriors World|last=Tsan|first=Pin|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/blog/golden-state-warriors/post/_/id/1313/draymond-green-as-the-top-center-its-no-joke|title=Warriors' Draymond Green as NBA's top center? It's no joke|work=ESPN.com|access-date=August 6, 2017}}</ref> The lineup originally included [[Harrison Barnes]], who was replaced by former league MVP Durant in 2016–17, when the group also began to be known as the "'''Hamptons Five'''".<ref name="mercurynews.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.mercurynews.com/2016/12/05/warriors-monday-mailbag-whats-up-with-the-center-spot-death-lineup-overuse/|title=Warriors Monday Mailbag: What’s up with the center spot? Death lineup overuse?|author=|date=December 5, 2016|website=mercurynews.com|accessdate=January 25, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/nba-power-rankings-warriors-back-180711375.html|title=NBA Power Rankings: Warriors back into top spot, Raptors up to third|author=|date=|website=yahoo.com|accessdate=January 25, 2018}}</ref>
The Death Lineup is considered to be indicative of a larger overall trend in the NBA towards "positionless" basketball, where traditional position assignments and roles have less importance.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://basketball.realgm.com/article/239916/The-Epitome-Of-Positionless-Basketball|title=The Epitome Of Positionless Basketball – RealGM Articles|website=basketball.realgm.com|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://orlandomagicdaily.com/2017/07/28/orlando-magic-embracing-positionless-basketball/|title=The Orlando Magic are embracing positionless basketball|date=July 28, 2017|website=Orlando Magic Daily|access-date=August 10, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/sports/sports-columns/ed-graney/positionless-basketball-defines-nbas-copycat-nature/|title=Positionless basketball defines NBA’s copycat nature|date=July 15, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|access-date=August 10, 2017|language=en-US}}</ref>
== History == In [[2014–15 Golden State Warriors season|2014–15]], Golden State won 67 games in the regular season, led by [[NBA MVP]] [[Stephen Curry]]. The Warriors' starting lineup with the {{convert|7|ft|adj=on}} [[Andrew Bogut]] at [[center (basketball)|center]] played 813 minutes together and outscored opponents by 19.6 points per 100 possessions. After falling behind 2–1 in the [[2015 NBA Finals]], Warriors coach [[Steve Kerr]] inserted [[Andre Iguodala]] into the starting unit for Bogut, who had been named to [[NBA All-Defensive Team]] in 2014.<ref name="golliver_06122016">{{cite news|last=Golliver|first=Ben|title=Warriors start small, then stay small, to blow out Cavs and even NBA Finals|date=June 12, 2015|work=SI.com|url=https://www.si.com/nba/2015/06/12/steve-kerr-nba-finals-andre-iguodala-lebron-james-game-4-warriors-cavaliers|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160521141920/https://www.si.com/nba/2015/06/12/steve-kerr-nba-finals-andre-iguodala-lebron-james-game-4-warriors-cavaliers|archivedate=May 21, 2016|deadurl=no}}</ref> The change was first suggested by Kerr's special assistant, Nick U'Ren, who was a fan of the lineup because it always seemed to pick up the pace of the game to a faster speed, which the Warriors preferred.<ref name=arnovitz_10142015/><ref name=kawakami_06033016>{{cite news|last=Kawakami|first=Tim|title=Nick U’Ren on the "Death Lineup" and what it does for the Warriors: "It works because there are no other players like those guys"|date=June 3, 2016|newspaper=The San Jose Mercury News|url=http://blogs.mercurynews.com/kawakami/2016/06/03/nick-uren/|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fblogs.mercurynews.com%2Fkawakami%2F2016%2F06%2F03%2Fnick-uren%2F&date=2017-06-10|archivedate=June 10, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> The five-man lineup of Iguodala, Curry, Thompson, Green, and Barnes had played together for 102 minutes during the regular season and 62 minutes through the first 18 games of the playoffs.<ref name=arnovitz_10142015/> Although the tallest player was only {{convert|6|ft|8|in}}, the unit was also strong defensively.<ref name="greenberg_05122016" /> They were all able to switch on defense,<ref name="alipour_12082015">{{cite news|url=http://www.espn.com.au/nba/story/_/id/14314860/stephen-curry-small-ball-mj-gunning-record-books|title=Stephen Curry on copying the Warriors' way: 'You won't have the personnel'|last=Alipour|first=Sam|date=December 8, 2015|work=ESPN The Magazine|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.espn.com.au%2Fnba%2Fstory%2F_%2Fid%2F14314860%2Fstephen-curry-small-ball-mj-gunning-record-books&date=2017-06-11|archivedate=June 11, 2016|deadurl=no}}</ref> spearheaded by Green's ability to guard players taller and heavier than him.<ref name="greenberg_05122016">{{cite news|last=Greenberg|first=Neil|title=No one can stop the Warriors’ small-ball lineup|date=May 12, 2016|newspaper=The Washington Post|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fancy-stats/wp/2016/05/12/no-one-can-stop-the-warriors-small-ball-lineup/|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6r6zE6Egw?url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fancy-stats/wp/2016/05/12/no-one-can-stop-the-warriors-small-ball-lineup/|archivedate=June 10, 2017|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Lowe|first=Zach|title=One year later, Draymond Green has no regrets|date=June 9, 2017|website=ESPN.com|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/19581798/zach-lowe-golden-state-warriors-forgiving-draymond-green-2017-nba-finals|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.espn.com%2Fnba%2Fstory%2F_%2Fid%2F19581798%2Fzach-lowe-golden-state-warriors-forgiving-draymond-green-2017-nba-finals&date=2017-06-11|archivedate=June 11, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> The Warriors won 103–82 in Game 4,<ref name="golliver_06122016" /> and captured the series 4–2 to win their first championship since [[1975 NBA Finals|1975]].<ref name="kawakami_06012016">{{cite news|url=http://blogs.mercurynews.com/kawakami/2016/06/01/death-lineup-unleashed-cleveland-last-years-finals-probably-will-time/|title=How the Warriors’ "Death Lineup" was unleashed on Cleveland in last year’s Finals, and probably will be again this time|last=Kawakami|first=Tim|date=June 1, 2016|newspaper=The San Jose Mercury News|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fblogs.mercurynews.com%2Fkawakami%2F2016%2F06%2F01%2Fdeath-lineup-unleashed-cleveland-last-years-finals-probably-will-time%2F&date=2017-06-10|archivedate=June 10, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> Iguodala was named the [[Bill Russell NBA Finals Most Valuable Player Award|Finals MVP]], becoming the first player to garner the award without starting every game in the series,<ref>{{cite news |last=Strauss |first=Ethan Sherwood |title=Andre Iguodala named Finals MVP after coming off bench to begin series |date=June 16, 2015 |work=ESPN.com |url=http://espn.go.com/nba/playoffs/2015/story/_/id/13096860/andre-iguodala-golden-state-warriors-named-nba-finals-mvp |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ZLZkTHuI?url=http://espn.go.com/nba/playoffs/2015/story/_/id/13096860/andre-iguodala-golden-state-warriors-named-nba-finals-mvp |archivedate=June 17, 2015 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }}</ref> as well as the first winner to have not started a game during the regular season.<ref>{{cite news|last=Sarecevic|first=Al|title=Andre Iguodala: unlikely Finals MVP|date=June 17, 2015|newspaper=The San Francisco Chronicle|url=http://www.sfgate.com/warriors/article/Iguodala-Unlikely-Finals-MVP-6331753.php|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.sfgate.com%2Fwarriors%2Farticle%2FIguodala-Unlikely-Finals-MVP-6331753.php&date=2017-06-11|archivedate=June 11, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref>
It took months after it was deployed in the Finals before the Warriors' small lineup was referred to as the Death Lineup.<ref name=arnovitz_10142015>{{cite news|last=Arnovitz|first=Kevin|title=How the Warriors discovered the cheat code to basketball in the 2015 NBA Finals|date=October 14, 2015|website=ESPN.com|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/15062110/warriors-discovered-cheat-code-basketball-nba-finals|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.espn.com%2Fnba%2Fstory%2F_%2Fid%2F15062110%2Fwarriors-discovered-cheat-code-basketball-nba-finals&date=2017-06-10|archivedate=June 11, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name=jenkins_06072016>{{cite news|last=Jenkins|first=Lee|title=The birth of the Warriors' death lineup|date=June 7, 2016|work=Sports Illustrated|url=https://www.si.com/nba/2016/06/07/golden-state-warriors-death-lineup-nba-finals-cleveland-cavaliers|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.si.com%2Fnba%2F2016%2F06%2F07%2Fgolden-state-warriors-death-lineup-nba-finals-cleveland-cavaliers&date=2017-06-10|archivedate=June 10, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> Despite the unit's success, the [[2015–16 Golden State Warriors season|2015–16 Warriors]] continued to start a traditional lineup with Bogut as their center.<ref>{{cite news|last=Davis|first=Scott|title=The NBA is still trying to solve the Warriors' deadliest weapon|date=February 12, 2016|work=Business Insider|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/warriors-small-ball-lineup-cant-be-solved-2016-2|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160423144516/http://www.businessinsider.com/warriors-small-ball-lineup-cant-be-solved-2016-2|archivedate=April 23, 2016|deadurl=no}}</ref> Golden State won an NBA-record 73 games behind Curry's league-leading 30.1 points per game and an NBA-record 402 three-pointers made in a season. He was named the MVP for the second straight season, becoming the first unanimous winner in league history.<ref>{{cite news|title=Warriors’ Stephen Curry first player to win unanimous MVP|date=May 10, 2016|website=SI.com|url=https://www.si.com/nba/2016/05/10/stephen-curry-unanimous-mvp-golden-state-warriors|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.si.com%2Fnba%2F2016%2F05%2F10%2Fstephen-curry-unanimous-mvp-golden-state-warriors&date=2017-06-11|archivedate=June 11, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> During the season, the Death Lineup was generally reserved to finish the first half and the end of games.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lou|first=William|title=Kerr: Warriors will play Death Lineup with Durant at power forward|date=September 4, 2016|work=TheScore|url=https://www.thescore.com/nba/news/1092473-kerr-warriors-will-play-death-lineup-with-durant-at-power-forward|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.thescore.com%2Fnba%2Fnews%2F1092473-kerr-warriors-will-play-death-lineup-with-durant-at-power-forward&date=2017-06-10|archivedate=June 10, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> It was deployed in 37 games, outscoring opponents by 166 points in 172 minutes for an average advantage of 4.5 points per game and 47.0 points per 100 possessions.<ref name=kawakami_06012016/><ref name=jenkins_06072016/><ref>{{cite news|last=Wagner|first=Kyle|title=The Warriors Aren’t A Small-Ball Team Anymore|date=June 1, 2017|work=FiveThirtyEight|url=https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-warriors-arent-a-small-ball-team-anymore/|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=https%3A%2F%2Ffivethirtyeight.com%2Ffeatures%2Fthe-warriors-arent-a-small-ball-team-anymore%2F&date=2017-06-10|archivedate=June 10, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Slater|first=Anthony|title=Examining five early season Warriors trends by the numbers|date=October 31, 2016|newspaper=The San Jose Mercury News|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/2016/10/31/examining-five-early-season-warriors-trends-by-the-numbers/|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mercurynews.com%2F2016%2F10%2F31%2Fexamining-five-early-season-warriors-trends-by-the-numbers%2F&date=2017-06-10|archivedate=June 10, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> Despite their regular season success, the Warriors lost the [[2016 NBA Finals]], becoming the first team to lose a Finals series after being ahead 3–1.<ref name="price_07044016">{{cite news|last=Price|first=Dwayne|title=Mavericks back in business with Warriors exes Bogut, Barnes on board|date=July 4, 2016|newspaper=Star-Telegram|url=http://www.star-telegram.com/sports/nba/dallas-mavericks/article87588567.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161008192803/http://www.star-telegram.com/sports/nba/dallas-mavericks/article87588567.html|archivedate=October 8, 2016|deadurl=no}}</ref>
During the off-season, Golden State signed former league MVP and four-time scoring champion [[Kevin Durant]] to replace [[Harrison Barnes]], who had averaged just five points and made only 5 of 32 shots during the last three losses in the Finals.<ref name="price_07044016" /><ref>{{cite news|last=Golliver|first=Ben|title=Grades: Warriors outdo themselves with Kevin Durant blockbuster deal|date=July 4, 2016|website=SI.com|url=https://www.si.com/nba/2016/07/04/kevin-durant-warriors-thunder-nba-free-agency-contract-grades-stephen-curry|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.si.com%2Fnba%2F2016%2F07%2F04%2Fkevin-durant-warriors-thunder-nba-free-agency-contract-grades-stephen-curry&date=2017-06-11|archivedate=June 11, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> With Durant leaving the [[Oklahoma City Thunder]], the Warriors' opponents in the [[2016 NBA Playoffs|2016 Western Conference Finals]], the move was seen as a disruption in the competitive balance of the NBA, and the Warriors instantly became title favorites.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.si.com/nba/2016/07/12/kevin-durant-warriors-superteam-black-lives-matter-bathroom-law-fouls|title=KD to Warriors bad for NBA? Adam Silver chimes in|last=Golliver|first=Ben|work=SI.com|access-date=August 6, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/sports/betting/kevin-durants-decision-makes-warriors-odds-on-nba-title-favorites/|title=Kevin Durant’s decision makes Warriors odds-on NBA title favorites|date=July 4, 2016|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|access-date=August 6, 2017|language=en-US}}</ref> The move gave the Death Lineup four players who have averaged at least five [[assist (basketball)|assists]] in a season.<ref>{{cite news|last=Ruiz|first=Steven|title=The Warriors new 'Death Lineup' is going to terrorize the NBA|date=July 4, 2016|newspaper=USA Today|url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2016/07/golden-state-warriors-death-lineup-kevin-durant|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fftw.usatoday.com%2F2016%2F07%2Fgolden-state-warriors-death-lineup-kevin-durant&date=2017-06-10|archivedate=June 10, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> [[San Francisco Bay Area]] journalist [[Tim Kawakami]] coined the nickname "Hamptons Five" for the new group, which included the four players who traveled with team officials to [[The Hamptons]] to recruit Durant.<ref name="mercurynews.com"/><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eWg3DwAAQBAJ&pg=PA28&lpg=PA28|title=Golden Days: West's Lakers, Steph's Warriors, and the California Dreamers who Reinvented Basketball|first=Jack|last=McCallum|page=28|year=2017|publisher=Ballantine Books|accessdate=January 25, 2018|via=Google Books|isbn=9780399179075}}</ref><ref name=stein_05072018/> The Warriors won the [[2017 NBA Finals]] 4–1, and Durant was unanimously voted the Finals MVP.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/article/2017/06/13/kevin-durant-earns-finals-mvp|title=Golden State Warriors forward Kevin Durant claims Finals MVP|last=Blinebury|first=Fran|website=NBA.com|language=en|access-date=August 6, 2017}}</ref> Kerr had used the Death Lineup for just 16 minutes in the series until deploying it for 17 in the Game 5 clincher.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wagner|first1=Kyle|last2=Herring|first2=Chris|title=They Are Kevin Durant’s Warriors Now|date=June 13, 2017|work=FiveThirtyEight|url=https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/they-are-kevin-durants-warriors-now/?addata=espn:frontpage|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180218202842/https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/they-are-kevin-durants-warriors-now/?addata=espn:frontpage|archivedate=February 18, 2018|deadurl=no}}</ref> Iguodala scored 20 points in 38 minutes after averaging less than 30 minutes in the first four games of the series. Kerr used him in the small-ball lineup in favor of big men [[Zaza Pachulia]] (10 minutes) and [[JaVale McGee]] (0).<ref>{{cite news|last=Kawakami|first=Tim|title=Coaching edge: Steve Kerr’s best move of the championship-clinching Game 5|date=June 13, 2017|newspaper=The Mercury News|url=https://www.mercurynews.com/2017/06/13/coaching-edge-steve-kerrs-best-move-of-the-championship-clinching-game-5/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171010023510/https://www.mercurynews.com/2017/06/13/coaching-edge-steve-kerrs-best-move-of-the-championship-clinching-game-5/|archivedate=October 10, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref>
Injuries limited Golden States' use of the Death Lineup in [[2017–18 Golden State Warriors season|2017–18]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Mahoney|first=Rob|title=The Warriors' Death Lineup Is on Ice|date=January 5, 2018|work=Sports Illustrated|url=https://www.si.com/nba/2018/01/05/warriors-stephen-curry-kevin-durant-klay-thompson-stats-schedule|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180116003026/https://www.si.com/nba/2018/01/05/warriors-stephen-curry-kevin-durant-klay-thompson-stats-schedule|archivedate=January 16, 2018|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name=kawakami_01262018>{{cite news|last=Kawakami|first=Tim|title=The Warriors' Death Lineup isn't so revolutionary these days, but it's still the unit opponents fear the most|date=January 26, 2018|work=The Athletic|url=https://theathletic.com//222735/2018/01/26/kawakami-the-warriors-death-lineup-isnt-so-revolutionary-these-days-but-its-still-the-unit-opponents-fear-the-most/|subscription=yes}}</ref> Opponents had also adapted by rarely leaving their centers in the game against the Warriors' small lineup. Through 49 games, the unit had a -1.2 [[plus-minus]] rating.<ref name=kawakami_01262018/> However, it was still considered the team's most potent lineup.<ref name=dubin_03072018/><ref name=kawakami_01262018/><ref>{{cite news|last=Kurtenback|first=Dieter|title=What we learned in the Warriors’ emphatic win over the Thunder|date=February 25, 2018|newspaper=The Mercury News|url=https://www.mercurynews.com/2018/02/25/golden-state-warriors-vs-oklahoma-city-thunder-russell-westbrook-zaza-pachulia-highlights-video-kevin-durant-stephen-curry/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180226223647/https://www.mercurynews.com/2018/02/25/golden-state-warriors-vs-oklahoma-city-thunder-russell-westbrook-zaza-pachulia-highlights-video-kevin-durant-stephen-curry/|archivedate=February 26, 2018|deadurl=no}}</ref> In the final 17 games of the regular season, the Warriors were 7–10 with Curry missing all but one game after an ankle and later a knee injury. Durant, Thompson, Green, and Iguodala each missed four to eight games as well.<ref>{{cite news|last=Slater|first=Anthony|title=Five observations on the Warriors' 119-79 blowout loss in Utah to cap the regular season|date=April 11, 2018|work=The Athletic|url=https://theathletic.com/307739/2018/04/11/five-observations-on-the-warriors-119-79-blowout-loss-in-utah-to-cap-the-regular-season/|subscription=yes}}</ref> In Game 4 of the conference semifinals in the [[2018 NBA Playoffs|2018 playoffs]], Kerr started the Hamptons Five with Durant for the first time ever, and they posted a plus-minus of +26 in 18 minutes to lead a 118–92 win over the [[New Orleans Pelicans]], giving Golden State a 3–1 lead in the series.<ref name=stein_05072018>{{cite news|last=Stein|first=Marc|title=To Dominate in New Orleans and Beyond, the Warriors Head to the Hamptons|date=May 7, 2018|newspaper=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/07/sports/warriors-hamptons-five.html}}</ref> After eliminating the Pelicans in five games, the Warriors continued with the starting lineup in the conference finals to build a 2–1 series lead against the [[Houston Rockets]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Botemps|first=Tim|title=Rockets draw even with Warriors in Western Conference finals|date=May 22, 2018|newspaper=The Washington Post|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/sports/wp/2018/05/22/nba-playoffs-golden-state-warriors-houston-rockets-game-4/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180527222555/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/sports/wp/2018/05/22/nba-playoffs-golden-state-warriors-houston-rockets-game-4/|archivedate=May 27, 2018|deadurl=no}}</ref> Golden State won the series 4–3, but Iguodala missed the last four games with a bruised leg.<ref>{{cite news|title=Warriors reach 4th straight NBA Finals with win over Houston|date=May 29, 2018|website=ESPN.com|agency=Associated Press|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/recap?gameId=401032767|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180529100130/http://www.espn.com/nba/recap?gameId=401032767|archivedate=May 29, 2018|deadurl=no}}</ref> The Warriors entered the NBA Finals for the fourth straight time versus their longterm rivals, the [[Cleveland Cavaliers]]. They swept the Cavaliers in four games, leading to their third championship in four years.
== See also == {{portal|National Basketball Association}} * [[Cavaliers–Warriors rivalry]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Georg Melches Stadion | nickname = | logo_image = | image = Georg Melches Stadion.JPG | image_size = 300px | caption = | fullname = Georg Melches Stadion Essen | location = Hafenstrasse 97a
45356 [[Essen]]
[[Germany]] | coordinates = {{Coord|51|29|09|N|6|58|40|E|region:DE-NW_type:landmark|display=it}} | publictransit = | built = 1923 | opened = 1923 | renovated = 1939, 1948, 1954, 1977, 1994, 2005 | closed = 19 May 2012 | demolished = 21 May 2012 | owner = Municipality of Essen | operator = | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = Stadion Phönixstrasse (1923–1937)
Stadion Rot-Weiss (1937–1939)
Stadion an der Hafenstrasse (1939–1964) | tenants = [[Rot-Weiss Essen]] (1939–2012)
[[German national football team]] (Selected matches) | seating_capacity = 15,000 | dimensions = 105 × 68 m }} '''Georg-Melches-Stadion''' was a [[stadium]] in [[Essen]], [[Germany]]. It was built in 1923, renovated to the former state in 1939, 1948 and 1954{{cite web|url=http://www.martijnmureau.nl/vergane-glorie-georg-melches-stadion/ |title=History of the Georg Melches Stadion |publisher=martijnmureau.nl |date= |accessdate=4 January 2016}} and had a capacity of 30,000. Due to safety reasons this was reduced to 15,000 from 1994 onwards. It was used, mostly, for [[Association football|football]] matches of [[Rot-Weiss Essen]] and concerts. The stadium was demolished by August 2012. In 1920, the predecessor of Rot-Weiss Essen bought a piece of land at the PHönixstrasse (which was later renamed to Hafenstrasse). After the purchase it appeared that the land was too short to build a stadium. In the years after, the club purchased the remaining lands and construction of the stadium began. In 1923 the club built three stands, which could hold 10,00 spectators. In 1939 the club built a new stadium on the same location, allowing the capacity to grow to roughly 27,000. During the [[World War II|Second World War]] the stadium was heavily damaged. In 1948 the renovation and reconstruction of it was finished and in the early 1950s Rot-Weiss Essen planned on building a new multifunctional main stand. The ideas behind this new main stand would be a revolution on the European mainland.{{cite book | first = Uwe| last = Wick | title = An der Hafenstraße, RWE! | publisher = Verlag die Werkstatt | location = Götingen | year = 2011 | page = 205| isbn = 978-3-89533-820-5}} Georg Melches had a vision a multifunctional stand, in which a sporthall, a sauna, offices, residential units, commercial units and a press room were present. The construction would be made out of concrete and in 1954 the building was officially inaugurated. German and European papers were positive on these developments and even called the stadium the German Highbury, as an example to Arsenal’s former stadium. In 1952 Rot-Weiss Essen won the German Cup and in 1954 it won the German national championship. In 1956 Georg Melches and Rot-Weiss Essen installed the first floodlight installation of [[BRD (Germany)|West Germany]]. The stadium was an example for other stadiums. Due to medical conditions, Georg Melches stepped down and died in 1963. In 1964 Rot-Weiss Essen renamed the stadium to the Georg Melches Stadion.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} After Melches’ death, Rot-Weiss Essen couldn’t have the same successes as in the 1950s. It also appeared that all the club’s money was invested in the stadium and the club had troubles in investing the little money left in new players. When West Germany was chosen as hosts for the [[1974 FIFA World Cup]], the club hoped investors and the municipality of Essen would invest into the stadium to make it a host for the World Cup. This didn’t happen and rivals [[FC Schalke 04|Schalke 04]] and [[Borussia Dortmund]] built a new stadium to host matches for the World Cup. With the little money left, Rot-Weiss Essen invested in renovating the stadium in 1975. Relegation from the 1. Bundesliga in 1977 and financial problems forced the club to sell the Georg Melches Stadium to Essen in 1979. The municipality of Essen invested almost nothing in the renovation of the stadium and due to safety reasons parts of the stadium were closed down and demolished in 1994. The capacity was reduced to 15,000. In 2010 it was announced that Rot-Weiss Essen would build a new stadium 100 meters from the Georg Melches Stadion. One of the stands was cut into half, leaving the stadium with only 2.5 stands. On May 19, 2012, Rot-Weiss Essen played their last match in the stadium against [[Fortuna Köln]]. Two days later the Georg Melches Stadion was demolished and in August 2012 the [[Stadion Essen]] was opened. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons|Georg Melches Stadion}} *[http://www.martijnmureau.nl/vergane-glorie-georg-melches-stadion/ History of the Georg Melches Stadion] {{Rot-Weiss Essen}} [[Category:Football venues in Germany]] [[Category:Rot-Weiss Essen]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Essen]] [[Category:Sports venues in North Rhine-Westphalia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1939]] [[Category:Sports venues demolished in 2012]] [[Category:Demolished sports venues in Germany]]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Große EWE Arena
Large EWE Arena | nickname = | image = [[Image:Oldenburg Grosse EWE Arena 02.jpg|250px]]
[[Image:Oldenburg Grosse EWE Arena 01.jpg|250px]] | fullname = | location = [[Oldenburg]], [[Lower Saxony]]
{{flagicon|Germany}} [[Germany]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = 2012 | built = | opened = 2013 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = City of Oldenburg | operator = | surface = [[Parquet]] | construction_cost = [[Euro sign|€]]38.6 million[http://www.nwzonline.de/oldenburg/wirtschaft/fuer-die-neue-halle-muss-manch-altes-teil-weichen_a_1,0,560352137.html Für die neue Halle muss manch altes Teil weichen {{de icon}}.] | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[EWE Baskets Oldenburg]] ([[Basketball]])
(2013 – Present) | seating_capacity = '''Große EWE Arena'''
[[Concerts]]: 8,000[http://www.ewe-arena.de/ EWE Arena seating capacity detail {{de icon}}.]
[[Boxing]]: 7,396
[[Basketball]]: 6,069
[[Team handball|Handball]]: 5,532
[[Equestrianism]]: 4,228 | dimensions = | scoreboard = }} '''Große EWE Arena''', or Grosse EWE Arena, ([[English language|English]]: Large EWE Arena) is a dual [[indoor arena|indoor sporting arena]] complex that is located in [[Oldenburg]], [[Germany]]. It is a part of the [[Weser-Ems Halle]] multi-sporting complex, which contains two main sports arena halls, the small [[Kleine EWE Arena]], and the large Große EWE Arena. The facility's name comes from a sponsorship arrangement with the German energy and telecommunications company {{ill|EWE AG|de}}. The Große EWE arena has a seating capacity of 8,000 for [[concerts]],[http://www.ewe-arena.de/ EWE Arena seating capacity detail {{de icon}}.] 7,396 for [[boxing]] matches, 6,069 for [[basketball]] games, 5,532 for [[Team handball|handball]] games, and 4,228 for [[Equestrianism|equestrian]] competitions. It is the home arena of the professional [[basketball]] team [[EWE Baskets Oldenburg]], of the [[Basketball Bundesliga|German League]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://archive.is/20130628030134/http://www.weser-ems-halle.de/content.php?view=3&subview=80&PHPSESSID=15d4203bc94634dc243979b7bce07223 Official Website Große EWE Arena] {{de icon}} *[http://www.ewe-arena.de/ Große EWE Arena Official Website] {{de icon}} *[http://www.nwz-inside.de/images/201303/original/51238_news_1.jpg Große EWE Arena Picture] {{coord|53|08|49|N|8|13|36|E|display=title|region:DE-NI_type:landmark_source:dewiki}} [[Category:2013 establishments in Germany]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2013]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Germany]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Germany]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Oldenburg]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Oldenburg]] [[Category:Sports venues in Lower Saxony]] [[Category:Sport in Oldenburg]] [[Category:VfL Oldenburg]] {{Germany-sports-venue-stub}} {{LowerSaxony-struct-stub}} [[de:EWE Arena#Große EWE Arena]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Use British English|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox stadium | name = Holiday Park | nickname = | image = | caption = | fullname = | location = [[Durham, England|Durham]], [[England]] | coordinates = {{Coord|54.7807|-1.5769|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1923 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | surface = Grass | cost = | architect = | capacity = | record_attendance = 7,182 | dimensions = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = [[Durham City A.F.C.|Durham City]]
Greyhound racing (1937–1954) }} '''Holiday Park''' was a [[association football|football]] ground and [[Greyhound racing in the United Kingdom|greyhound racing]] stadium in [[Durham, England|Durham]] in [[England]]. It was the home ground of [[Durham City A.F.C.|Durham City]] between 1923 and 1939. ==History== Holiday Park opened in 1923 when Durham City left their [[Kepier Haughs]] ground. The club brought the wooden seated stand from the previous ground, which remained the only spectator facility at Holiday Park during the club's spell in [[the Football League]]. The first League match at the ground was played on 1 September 1923, with 4,000 spectators watching a 0–0 draw with [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]] The ground's record attendance of 7,182 was set soon afterwards for an FA Cup qualifying match against [[West Stanley F.C.|West Stanley]] on 17 September 1923.Paul Smith & Shirley Smith (2005) ''The Ultimate Directory of English & Scottish Football League Grounds Second Edition 1888–2005'', Yore Publications, p66, {{ISBN|0954783042}} Durham were voted out of the Football League in 1928, and the last Football League match was played at Holiday Park on 5 May 1928, when 5,000 spectators saw Durham beat [[Crewe Alexandra F.C.|Crewe Alexandra]] 5–1. In 1937 a new 2,000 capacity stand was built as the ground was adapted for greyhound racing. This involved reducing the size of the pitch, and ultimately caused Durham City to fold in 1938.[http://www.durhamcityafc.com/pages.php?page_id=131 History] Durham City A.F.C. The ground was subsequently expanded as it continued to be used for greyhound racing. It was later demolished, with the site used by the electricity board. ===Greyhound racing=== Independent (unaffiliated to a governing body) greyhound racing took place at Holiday Park from 23 October 1937 with the ground undergoing improvements including a new 2,000 capacity stand.{{cite web|url=https://www.old-maps.co.uk/#/Map/427284/542930/12/101200|title=OS County Series Durham 1939|publisher=old-maps.co.uk}} Racing ended in 1954.{{cite book|last=Barnes|first=Julia|title=Daily Mirror Greyhound Fact File|year=1988|publisher=Ringpress Books|isbn=0-948955-15-5}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{English greyhound tracks}} [[Category:Defunct football venues in England]] [[Category:Durham City A.F.C.]] [[Category:Defunct greyhound racing venues in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Durham, England]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1923]] [[Category:English Football League venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in County Durham]]

{{Multiple issues|{{refimprove|date=August 2013}}{{primary sources|date=August 2013}}{{one source|date=August 2013}}}} {{Infobox field hockey club | clubname = IGR Remscheid | image = File:IGR Remscheid Logo 2010.png | imagesize = | fullname = Rollsportverein IGR Remscheid | nickname = | founded = {{start date and age|1|4|1962}} | ground = Sporthalle Hackenberg,
[[Remscheid]], [[Germany]] | capacity = 400 | chairman = | manager = | director = | league = [[Rink Hockey Bundesliga|Bundesliga]] | season = | position = }} The '''IGR Remscheid''' is a [[Roller hockey (quad)|Roller Hockey]] team from [[Remscheid]], [[North Rhine-Westphalia]], [[Germany]]. ==History== Founded on 1 April 1962, IGR Remscheid won 5 German championships (1968, 69, 78, 92 and 94). In the preliminary round of the Rollhockey-Bundesliga 2015-16 IGR Remscheid finished on no. 7. For the first time in club history IGR Remscheid won the German cup in 2016. ==Trophies== *5 '''[[Rink Hockey Bundesliga|German Championship]]''' *1 '''German Cup''' ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.igr-remscheid.de IGR Remscheid Official Website] {{Rink hockey international competitions}} [[Category:Roller hockey clubs in Germany]] [[Category:Sports clubs established in 1962]] {{Germany-sport-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Use British English|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = Keep Fit | caption = | image = "Keep_Fit"_(1937).jpg | director = [[Anthony Kimmins]] | producer = [[Basil Dean]]
[[Jack Kitchin]] | writer = [[Anthony Kimmins]]
[[Austin Melford]] | narrator = | starring = [[George Formby]]
[[Kay Walsh]]
[[Guy Middleton]]
[[Evelyn Roberts]] | cinematography = [[John W. Boyle]]
[[Gordon Dines]]
[[Ronald Neame]] | music = [[Ernest Irving]] | editing = Ernest Aldridge | studio = [[Associated Talking Pictures]] | distributor = [[Associated British Film Distributors|ABFD]] | released = 1937 | runtime = 82 minutes | country = United Kingdom | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Keep Fit''''' is a 1937 [[United Kingdom|British]] [[comedy film]] directed by [[Anthony Kimmins]] and starring [[George Formby]], [[Kay Walsh]] and [[Guy Middleton]]. Formby was at his British top box-office peak when this comedy was made.{{cite web|url=http://skymovies.sky.com/keep-fit/review |title=Keep Fit - Sky Movies HD |publisher=Skymovies.sky.com |date=2002-05-23 |accessdate=2014-03-12}} ==Synopsis== [[George Formby, Jr.|George Formby]] again plays his [[working class]] [[underdog (competition)|underdog]], gormless, gullible, indefatigable and triumphant hero. A weakling, Formby's character overcomes obstacles to beat a corrupt rival in the [[boxing]] ring. He plays a scrawny barber's assistant who, in response to the keep fit fad sweeping through Britain at the time, dreams of a better physique, and sings of it in the catchy "Biceps, Muscle and Brawn". He falls in love with a beautiful manicurist, and competes for her affections with a muscle bound thug. The manicurist is more attracted to the brute until the barber can prove that he is a crook, and defeat him in the boxing ring.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmovie.com/movie/keep-fit-v97582 |title=Keep Fit (1937) - Trailers, Reviews, Synopsis, Showtimes and Cast |publisher=AllMovie |date= |accessdate=12 March 2014}}{{cite web|last=Nield |first=Anthony |url=http://film.thedigitalfix.com/content/id/72385/keep-fit.html#ixzz2t9B1QvG1 |title=''Keep Fit'' DVD Video Review|publisher=Film, the digital fix|date=8 April 2010|accessdate=12 March 2014}} ==Cast== * [[George Formby, Jr.|George Formby]] as George Freen * [[Kay Walsh]] as Joan Allen * [[Guy Middleton]] as Hector Kent * [[George Benson (actor)|George Benson]] as Ernie Gill * [[Gus McNaughton]] as "Echo" Publicity Manager * [[Evelyn Roberts]] as Mr Barker * [[Aubrey Mallalieu]] as Magistrate * [[Edmund Breon]] as Sir Augustus Marks * [[Hal Gordon]] as Reporter * [[Hal Walters]] as Racing Tough * [[C. Denier Warren]] as Editor * [[Edgar Driver]] as Boat Hire Owner * [[Leo Franklyn]] as Racing Tough * [[Robert Nainby]] as Judge At The Gym * [[Julian Vedey]] as Hairdressing Dept Head * Jack Vyvian as Boat Hire Man * [[D.J. Williams (actor)|D.J. Williams]] as Editor of The Gazette ==Critical reception== According to [[Sky Movies]] "it's a bouncy, confidently made comedy that's fun throughout and pretty hilarious in its boxing-ring conclusion".{{cite web|url=http://skymovies.sky.com/keep-fit/review |title=Keep Fit - Sky Movies HD |publisher=Skymovies.sky.com |date=23 May 2002|accessdate=12 March 2014}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== {{lacking ISBN|section|date=April 2015}} * Low, Rachael. ''Filmmaking in 1930s Britain''. George Allen & Unwin, 1985. * Perry, George. ''Forever Ealing''. Pavilion Books, 1994. * Wood, Linda. ''British Films, 1927-1939''. British Film Institute, 1986. == External links == * {{IMDb title|id=0029078|title=Keep Fit}} {{Anthony Kimmins}} [[Category:1930s comedy films]] [[Category:1930s sports films]] [[Category:1937 films]] [[Category:British films]] [[Category:British comedy films]] [[Category:British sports films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:British black-and-white films]] [[Category:Associated Talking Pictures]] [[Category:Films directed by Anthony Kimmins]] [[Category:Films set in England]] [[Category:Boxing films]] {{1930s-UK-comedy-film-stub}} {{sport-film-stub}}

Prokopčuka]] 1:12:52 (F; 2013) | homepage = http://www.kuldigas-pusmaratons.lv/ }} The '''Kuldīga Half Marathon''' is an annual road marathon, held in [[Kuldīga]], [[Latvia]]. The main sponsor of the marathon is [[SEB Unibanka|SEB]]. It is also the [[Latvian Athletics Championships|Latvian championship in half marathon]]. It is known as a tough half marathon - usually the weather in the old city's streets is rather hot, the track has many curves and most of the streets in the city are [[cobblestone]]d. ==Winners== '''Key:''' {{legend2|#A9F5A9|'''Course record'''|border=solid 1px #AAAAAA}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! {{main|LSU Tigers women's soccer}} {{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = LSU Soccer Stadium | location = Nicholson Drive
[[Baton Rouge, Louisiana|Baton Rouge]], [[Louisiana]] 70803
{{USA}} | image = [[File:LSU Soccer Stadium.jpg|300px]] | caption = | broke_ground = | built = 1996 | opened = September 13, 1996 | closed = | demolished = | owner = Louisiana State University | operator = LSU Athletics Department | construction_cost = | architect = | seating_capacity = 2,197 | tenants = [[LSU Tigers women's soccer]] ([[NCAA]]) }} [[File:LSU Soccer Stadium (Baton Rouge, LA).jpg|thumb|300px|LSU Soccer Stadium]] The '''LSU Soccer Stadium''' is a [[Association football|soccer]] facility located on the campus of [[Louisiana State University]] in [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana|Baton Rouge]], [[United States]]. The facility was built in 1996. It serves as the home of the [[LSU Tigers women's soccer]] team.{{cite web|url=http://www.lsusports.net/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=5200&ATCLID=177183|title=LSU Soccer Facilities|publisher=lsusports.net|accessdate=2013-03-09}} The two-level [[stadium]] has a [[seating capacity]] of 2,197. In 2010 and 2011, the soccer stadium received extensive renovations which included a second-level of seating, a new press box and wrought-iron style gates and fencing with brick columns were built on the west side of the complex.{{cite web|url=http://theadvocate.com/sports/saints/796670-64/lsu-set-to-open-new.html|title=LSU set to open new soccer stadium|publisher=theadvocate.com|accessdate=2013-03-09}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wafb.com/story/15415562/lsu-soccer-stadium-grand-opening-to-highlight-this-weeks-invitational|title=LSU Soccer Stadium grand opening highlights 2011 Invitational|publisher=wafb.com|accessdate=2013-03-09}} ==See also== *[[LSU Tigers and Lady Tigers]] *[[List of soccer stadiums in the United States]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.lsusports.net/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=5200&ATCLID=177183 LSU Soccer Stadium at LSUSports.net] {{Louisiana State University|athletics}} {{coord|30.4311|N|91.1781|W|source:wikidata-and-enwiki-cat-tree_region:US|display=title}} [[Category:College soccer venues in the United States]] [[Category:LSU Tigers women's soccer venues]] [[Category:Louisiana sports venue stubs]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Louisiana]] [[Category:Southern United States sports venue stubs]] [[Category:Sports venues in Louisiana]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1996]] [[Category:1996 establishments in Louisiana]] {{BatonRougeLA-sports-venue-stub}}

[[File:Judit The Look Polgar.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Judit Polgar]]]] [[File:Mikhail Tal 1961 Oberhausen.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Mikhail Tal]] 1961]] [[File:Botvinnik 1933.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Mikhail Botvinnik]]]] [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 102-00457, Emanuel Lasker.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Emanuel Lasker]]]] [[File:Wilhelm Steinitz2.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Wilhelm Steinitz]]]] <!-- Commented out: [[File:SammyReshevsky.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Samuel Reshevsky]]]] --> [[File:Tarrasch 72.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Siegbert Tarrasch]]]] <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Bronstein D 01.JPG|thumb|150px|[[David Bronstein]]]] --> [[File:Aron Nimzowitsch.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Aron Nimzowitsch]]]] [[File:Akiba-RubinsteinC.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Akiba Rubinstein]]]] [[File:Viktor Kortschnoi, 2009 in Zurich.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Viktor Korchnoi]]]] [[File:Kasparov-29.jpg|thumb|right|150px|[[Garry Kasparov]]]] [[File:Ksawery_Tartakower.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Savielly Tartakower]]]] [[File:Bobby Fischer 1960 in Leipzig.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Bobby Fischer]]]] [[File:Boris Gelfand.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Boris Gelfand]]]] Jewish players and game theoreticians have long been involved in the game of chess and have significantly contributed to the development of chess, which has been described as the "Jewish National game".
Although making up less than 0.2% of the world's population, of the first 13 undisputed [[Chess world champion|world champions]], over 50% were Jewish, including the first two. The Modern school of chess espoused by [[Wilhelm Steinitz]] and [[Siegbert Tarrasch]]; the [[Hypermodernism (chess)|Hypermodernism]] influenced by [[Aron Nimzowitsch]] and [[Richard Réti]]; and the [[Soviet Chess School]] promoted by [[Mikhail Botvinnik]] were all strongly influenced by Jewish players. Other influential Jewish chess theoreticians, writers and players include [[Johannes Zukertort|Zukertort]], [[Savielly Tartakower|Tartakower]], [[Emanuel Lasker|Lasker]], [[Akiba Rubinstein|Rubinstein]], [[Gyula Breyer|Breyer]], [[Rudolf Spielmann|Spielmann]], [[Samuel Reshevsky|Reshevsky]], [[Reuben Fine|Fine]], [[David Bronstein|Bronstein]], [[Miguel Najdorf|Najdorf]], [[Mikhail Tal|Tal]], [[Bobby Fischer|Fischer]], and [[Judit Polgár|Polgár]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Winter|first=Edward|title=Chess and Jews|url=http://www.chesshistory.com/winter/extra/jews.html|publisher=chesshistory.com|accessdate=2003}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Greatest Chess Players|url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chesscollection?cid=1004505|publisher=Chessgame.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Berkovich|first=Felix|title=Jewish Chess Masters on Stamps|year=2000|publisher=McFarland|location=Jefferson, NC|pages=Chapter 5}}</ref> Professor [[Arpad Elo]], the inventor of the scientific rating system employed by the [[FIDE]] analysed some 476 major tournament players from the nineteenth century onward and of the fifty-one highest ranked players, approximately one-half were Jewish.<ref>{{cite book|last=Elo|first=Arpad|title=The Rating of Chess Players, Past and Present|year=1978|publisher=ARCO|location=New York}}</ref> One of the strongest ever players was the half Jewish [[Garry Kasparov]], who was world No. 1 from 1985 until his retirement in 2005; however Kasparov has described himself as a "self-appointed Christian"<ref>[[Garry Kasparov]]</ref> preferring to follow his mother's faith. The strongest female chess player in history by far is the Jewish [[Judit Polgár]].<ref>{{cite web|title=World Top Chess players|url=http://ratings.fide.com/toplist.phtml?list=men|publisher=FIDE}}</ref> There is currently a strong Jewish presence among the world's best players. Currently, the world number two, [[Levon Aronian]] from Armenia, is half-Jewish. [[Beersheba]] in Israel is the city with the most chess [[Grandmaster (chess)|grandmasters]] per capita in the world.<ref>{{cite web|last=Rabinowitz|first=Gavin|title=Beersheba Masters Kings, Knights, Pawns|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2005/jan/30/news/adfg-ichess30|publisher=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=January 30, 2005}}</ref> Israel has also won one silver and one bronze medal at [[Chess Olympiad]]s.<ref>http://www.olimpbase.org/index.html?http%3A%2F%2Fwww.olimpbase.org%2Folympiads%2Fmen_results.html</ref>
The topic of Jewish participation in chess is discussed extensively in academic and popular literature. One such book devoted to the topic is ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=qhz9AAAACAAJ The Great Jewish Chess Champions]'' by Harold U. Ribalow and Meir Z. Ribalow, [[Hippocrene Books]], 1987, {{ISBN|0-87052-305-8}}. Others include ''[http://www.getcited.org/pub/100093138 Chess, Jews, and history]'', by [[Victor Keats]], 1994, Oxford Academia Publishers, {{ISBN|1-899237-00-3}}, [http://www.getcited.org/pub/100093139 ''Chess Among the Jews: A Translation and Explanation of the Work of Moritz Steinschneider''], by Victor Keats, 1995, {{ISBN|1-899237-02-X}}, ''[http://www.getcited.org/pub/100307178 Chess in Jewish history and Hebrew literature]'', by Victor Keats, 1995, Magnes Press, {{ISBN|965-223-915-1}}, and [https://books.google.com/books?id=gGoqKT91lMsC&dq=jews+chess&lr=&source=gbs_navlinks_s ''Can I Play Chess on Shabbas''], by Joe Bobker, 2008, {{ISBN|965-229-422-5}}. ''See also'' ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=HNW3AAAAIAAJ&q=jewish+chess&dq=jewish+chess&hl=en&ei=lVqLTfX9Io68sQPtxcWICg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=book-thumbnail&resnum=1&ved=0CDMQ6wEwAA Jewish chess masters on stamps]'', by Felix Berkovich and N. J. Divinsky, McFarland, 2000, {{ISBN|0-7864-0683-6}}. [[H.G. Wells]], himself a chessplayer, discusses the eminence of the Jewish race in chess, in his History of the World. The [[Museum of Jewish Heritage]] is developing a special gallery relating to Jews in sports and chess, which will recognize "major Jewish chess players such as Garry Kasparov, [[Mikhail Tal]], and Judith Polgar".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nmjh.org/sports.php?person=2 |title=Sports & Chess |publisher=[[The National Museum of Jewish Heritage]]|date= |author= |accessdate=March 28, 2011}}</ref>

{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = David M. MacAulay Field | nickname = | image = | fullname = | location = [[Mount Allison University]]
York Street
[[Sackville, New Brunswick|Sackville]], [[New Brunswick]] | coordinates = {{coord|45|53|52.75|N|64|22|25.10|W|region:CA}} | broke_ground = October 20, 1898 | built = | opened = October 1900 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Mount Allison University]] | operator = | surface = Grass | construction_cost = $1,000 | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = Athletic Field | tenants = [[Mount Allison Mounties]] | seating_capacity = 2,500 | dimensions = }} '''David M. MacAulay Field''' is a [[Canada|Canadian]] football stadium in [[Sackville, New Brunswick|Sackville]], [[New Brunswick]], that is host to the [[Mount Allison Mounties]]. ==History== Construction MacAulay Field began on October 20, 1898, and was opened in October 1900.[http://www.mta.ca/threecheers/facilitiesathleticfields02.html Mount Allison, History of Sports, Facilities] The land was bequeathed to the University in 1898 by George T. Bowser, and the field cost an estimated $1,000 to construct. It was then known as the Athletic Field and stretched 160 by 80 yards, with a running track encircled it. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.mta.ca Mount Allison University] {{coord|45|53|52.75|N|64|22|25.10|W|region:CA|display=title}} [[Category:Sports venues in New Brunswick]] [[Category:Canadian football venues]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Canada]] [[Category:Mount Allison University]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1900]] {{NewBrunswick-struct-stub}} {{Canada-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Unreferenced|date=November 2006}} [[File:GSU Auditorium Atlanta.JPG|thumb|GSU Dahlberg Hall, 2012]] [[File:Atlanta Auditorium 1910s.jpg|thumb|Atlanta Municipal Auditorium with original brick facade]] '''Atlanta Municipal Auditorium''', originally known as the ''Auditorium and Armory'', was an [[auditorium]] in [[Atlanta, Georgia]], USA. It was constructed with funds raised by a committee of Atlanta citizens and then sold to the city of Atlanta.
The structure was dedicated in a pre-inaugural visit from President [[William Howard Taft]] in 1909 during which he was served a [[Virginia opossum|possum]] dinner, and the dining hall in which this event took place was named in his honor. The public dedication of the Auditorium took place with the hosting of the inaugural Atlanta Music Festival in May 1909. The Auditorium and Armory also housed the 179th Field Artillery, who stored munitions there as well as using the space for drills.
Over the years various concerts, theater productions, [[opera]]s, balls, and [[professional wrestling]] matches were hosted at the auditorium, as were the 1922 to 1932 [[Southern Conference]] men's [[basketball]] tournaments. One additional event of note was the ''[[Gone with the Wind (film)|Gone with the Wind]]'' Ball, held in conjunction with the 1939 [[premiere]] of the film.
The building originally had a red [[brick]] [[facade]]. After a 1940 fire the original architect, [[John Robert Dillon]], redesigned the exterior and it was rebuilt with a [[marble]] facade.
Until [[Woodruff Arts Center]] opened, the Municipal Auditorium was the home of the [[Atlanta Symphony Orchestra]].
The building was sold in 1979 to [[Georgia State University]] which now uses the structure as their Alumni Hall. On September 17, 2010, Georgia State University renamed their Alumni Hall Dahlberg Hall, after alumnus A. W. "Bill" Dahlberg.
Atlanta Municipal Auditorium is located at Gilmer and Courtland Streets in [[downtown Atlanta]].
==External links== * [http://downhometraces.com/2009/04/17/wayne-daniel-on-the-old-city-auditorium Video documentary on history of building] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20160303234049/http://atlantatimemachine.com/downtown/armory.htm Historic photos of Municipal Auditorium on ''Atlanta Time Machine'']
{{Georgia State University}} {{Coord|33|45|13|N|84|23|4|W|display=t|type:landmark}}

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Queensland State Equestrian Centre | nickname = QSEC | image = | fullname = Queensland State Equestrian Centre | location = [[Caboolture, Queensland|Caboolture]], [[Brisbane]], [[Australia]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = August 2011 | opened = 3 September 2011 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Moreton Bay Regional Council | operator = Moreton Bay Regional Council | surface =Sand | construction_cost = [[Australian dollar|$]]17.28 million | architect = PDT Architects | structural engineer =Bornhorst & Ward | services engineer = | general_contractor=[[Walton Construction (Australia)|Walton Construction]] | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = | seating_capacity = 3,200 equestrian spectators or 5,000 for a concert | dimensions =80m x 40m (indoor) }}
'''Queensland State Equestrian Centre''' is an [[Equestrianism|equestrian]] sport venue located in [[Caboolture, Queensland|Caboolture]], [[Brisbane]], [[Australia]]. It was opened in September 2011.<ref>{{Cite web | title = Update on the Qld State Equestrian Centre | author = Nadya Marshall | date = 7 July 2011 | publisher = Equestrian Federation of Australia | accessdate = 2011-12-13 | url = http://www.efaq.com.au/?page=26474&format= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | title = Queensland State Equestrian Centre - Grand Opening a Great Success | publisher = Virtual Equestrian | accessdate = 2011-12-13 | url = http://equestrian.cyberhorse.com.au/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=8818:queensland-state-equestrian-centre-grand-opening-a-great-success&catid=3:feature-news }}</ref>
'''The facilities at QSEC include:'''
*An 80m x 40m indoor, sand arena with seating for 3,200 equestrian spectators or 5,200 for a concert, judges and commentators rooms and PA system *Warm up areas including a fully lit, 60m x 20m sand warm up arena *4 all-weather, sand dressage arenas with covered viewing areas *154 stables with anti-slip rubber matting *8 wash bays *55 camp sites with power and water access *Camp sites ('''see below''') *2 meeting/training rooms *A licensed bar
The Queensland State Equestrian Centre has 154 stables within close proximity to the camp sites, the main arena, warm up arena and dressage arenas.
'''Stable Facilities:'''
*154 stables measuring 3.6m x 3.6m with anti-slip rubber matting and bitumen aisles *Water and lighting in each aisle *8 wash bays *A dedicated vets room *Horse waste bays *A PA system link to the main arena *Sawdust bedding
The Queensland State Equestrian Centre has 55 camp sites with water and power access as well as additional ‘informal’ camping spaces. The camp sites are split into three different sizes allowing for large horse trucks, camper vans and goosenecks through to smaller horse trucks and horse floats. The width of all powered sites are 5.5m and the lengths vary from 16m to 25.5m.
'''Camping Facilities:'''
*55 camp sites with power and water access *Further unpowered camp sites *A large amenities block toilets and showers *Camping reception
==See also== * [[Sport in Brisbane]] * [[Sport in Queensland]]
==References== {{reflist}} {{cite journal |author= |year=2011 |title= State Equestrian Centre |journal= Australian National Construction Review |volume=04 |issue=|pages=152 |publisher= |issn= 1449-7344|doi= |pmid= |pmc= |url= }}
==External links== *[http://www.qsec.com.au/default.aspx Official website] {{coord|27.061323|S|152.948567|E|display=title}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Queensland State Equestrian Centre}} [[Category:Sports venues in Brisbane]] [[Category:Equestrian venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2011]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Australia]] [[Category:Equestrian sports in Australia]]

{{Malay name|Rahimni|Pundut}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Rahimni Pundut | fullname = Haji Rahimni bin Haji Pundut | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1987|01|05|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Brunei]] | height = {{convert|1.75|m|ftin|abbr=on}} | position = [[Forward (association football)|Striker]] | currentclub = [[Setia Perdana]] | clubnumber = 7 | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = | years1 = 2009 | caps1 = 1 | goals1 = 0| clubs1 = [[Brunei DPMM FC|DPMM]] | years2 = 2010– | caps2 = | goals2 = | clubs2 = [[Setia Perdana FC|Setia Perdana]] | nationalyears1= | nationalcaps1= | nationalgoals1= | nationalteam1= | club-update = 2 February 2017 | ntupdate = }}
'''Haji Rahimni bin Haji Pundut''' (born 5 January 1987) is a [[Brunei]]an [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Setia Perdana FC]] in the [[Brunei Super League]] as a [[Forward (association football)|striker]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Faisal one of Setia Perdana’s key players|url=http://borneobulletin.com.bn/faisal-one-of-setia-perdanas-key-players/|date=17 March 2016|publisher=Borneo Bulletin|accessdate=2 February 2017}}</ref> Due to a typing error, his patronym is mistakenly referred to as '''Pundat'''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sleague.com/Web/main.aspx?ID=e186a16b-ced4-4bad-a458-90e301728dc0|title=SLeague Portal: DPMM|publisher=[[S.League]]|date=|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090822045646/http://www.sleague.com/Web/main.aspx?ID=e186a16b-ced4-4bad-a458-90e301728dc0|archivedate=22 August 2009|accessdate=2 February 2017}}</ref>
==Career==
Rahimni previously played for professional club [[Brunei DPMM FC]] in the [[2009 S.League]] season, DPMM's first and eventful season in [[Singapore]] after withdrawing from the [[Malaysia Super League]]. He only saw one minute of playing time, against [[Sengkang Punggol FC|Sengkang Punggol]] on 6 July.<ref>{{cite web |title=Match Statistics for Match 0102 - Sengkang Punggol FC vs Brunei DPMM FC|url=http://www.sleague.com/match-details/?id=SL/09-0102|date=|publisher=S.League|accessdate=2 February 2017}}</ref> He was on the bench for the final of the [[2009 Singapore League Cup#Final|2009 Singapore League Cup]], picking up a winner's medal as DPMM won the game 4–3 on penalties after a 1–1 draw in extra time.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.redsports.sg/2009/06/20/league-cup-final-saffc-brunei-dpmm/|title=League Cup eludes SAFFC as Brunei DPMM FC win on penalties|publisher=Red Sports Singapore|date=20 June 2009|accessdate=2 February 2017}}</ref>
Rahimni moved to [[Setia Perdana]] in 2011 for the Brunei National Football League, a competition ran by the newly established [[National Football Association of Brunei Darussalam]] to determine the teams for a new league that was to become the [[2012–13 Brunei Super League]]. His club finished third in the one-off league, placing them in the [[2014 Brunei Premier League|2014]] [[Brunei Premier League]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Brunei 2011/12|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesb/brunei2012.html|date=13 December 2012|publisher=Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|accessdate=2 February 2017}}</ref>
On 31 May 2015, Rahimni scored a three-minute hattrick in a 4-2 victory against [[Kasuka FC]], a feat possibly yet to be equalled in Bruneian football.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bt.com.bn/sports-national/2015/06/01/hj-rahimni-stars-setia-perdana%E2%80%99s-victory|title=Hj Rahimni stars in Setia Perdana’s victory|publisher=The Brunei Times|date=1 June 2015|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160702234632/http://bt.com.bn/sports-national/2015/06/01/hj-rahimni-stars-setia-perdana%E2%80%99s-victory|archivedate=2 July 2016|accessdate=2 February 2017}}</ref> Rahimni finished the 2015 season as top scorer for the Brunei Premier League with 16 goals.<ref>{{cite web |title=DST PREMIER LEAGUE 2015 top scorers|url=http://nfabd.org/schedules/dst-premierleague-2015-scorer.htm|date=13 August 2015|publisher=[[National Football Association of Brunei Darussalam]]|accessdate=2 February 2017}}</ref>
Rahimni scored a total of seven goals to lift Setia Perdana to first place in the [[2017 Brunei Premier League]].<ref>{{cite web |title=IKLS promoted to DST Premier League with win over DSP United|url=https://borneobulletin.com.bn/ikls-promoted-to-dst-premier-league-with-win-over-dsp-united/|date=30 September 2017|publisher=Borneo Bulletin|accessdate=12 November 2018}}</ref> This brought promotion for Setia to the [[2018–19 Brunei Super League]].
== Honours == ===Team=== ;DPMM FC *[[Singapore League Cup]]: [[2009 Singapore League Cup|2009]]
;Setia Perdana *[[Brunei Premier League]]: [[2017 Brunei Premier League|2017]]
===Individual=== *[[2015 Brunei Premier League]] top scorer - 16 goals
== References == {{Reflist}}
